I have been in Trigg's public-house on two occasions—once about four years ago and once 18 years ago. I can fix the date by the age of nay son. Reverting to the Barker contract, it is a deliberate lie for Calcutt to suggest that one of the reasons I withdrew my name from the petition was that I had been

black-balled from some Masonic Lodge. I have never been. I moved, and it was seconded by Kemp, that the public should be admitted to the Board Room on November 17, 1904. I also moved that Knight's report should be in writing, in consequence of certain things he said which were different to his former statement. I might say that Mr. Knight has run us into a lot of trouble. As to the bills, we relied on the architect's certificate. If we could not rely on Knight, we could not rely on tailors and publicans. He was paid to measure up the work and got 5 per cent. When I came on the Board I found Calcutt was the contractor who usually did the work, and that influenced me in voting for him. He was work
ing under a schedule of prices prepared by Mr. Knight.
To Mr. Vachell. I used Calcutt's pony and governess cart on two occasions that were afterwards sold to Hirst. The pony went very badly.

Cross-examined by the Solicitor-General. I knew Calcutt before I went on the Board, and became on friendly terms with him two or three years before. We did not remain friendly all the while I was on the Board, because of the difficulty I had in getting accounts from him. I got to know Stammers when I joined the Board. I don't re
member Calcutt saying here, "If I could say anything that was true, either in favour of Ridpath, or any of the other Guardians, I would say it." I had cross words with him about the indestructible paint, because I was against the price he was expecting to get. I was under no obligation to vote for him. I do not think I could have been present when the report came before the Board as to the 1s. 6d., or I should have voted, as I thought it was double what it was worth. I did not know what the number of yards was. I think I was leaving the room to catch a train just as the question was being discussed. I pledge myself that I did not vote. I wanted to catch the 7.22 train at Burdett Road. Draper objected to the 1s. 6d. He is a man of position, and I would accept his word in some things. I heard him say that I voted and spoke in favour of the 1s. 6d. It is a mistake. I voted against Calcutt on some bath alterations in the Globe Road shortly after I got on the Board. I moved Jackson to do a job againt Calcutt, to put the floor down in the laundry-hand's dining room, or mess room. I also voted or supported the proposition that Jackson should have the job to do the lunatic ward against Calcutt about three years ago. I also supported Frank and Symons. I have been in the habit of going into Spooner's very often. I was Hon. Secretary of the Stepney Association for many years. I may have been there at the meeting sworn to by Calcutt a few days before December 22, 1904. I never remember meeting or seeing Calcutt there. I remember Cal
cutt's story about this. There is no truth in it so far as I am con
cerned. One of my objections to Barker's contract was that G. Barker was a member of the Mile End Board of Guardians and father of the proposed contractor, and also that the plant had the name and address of G. Barker upon it—also, that being Vice-Chairman of the Board, be could attend every Committee of the Board and hear every member's opinion, besides having his voice and vote upon any

item raised respecting the building operations. The letter of explana
tion removed those objections as far as I was concerned. I remember the meeting of the Board on February 9 and Barker, sen., saying, "It is a fact that all the plant upon the job now belongs alone to me and has my name upon it, but cannot I lend my son the plant?" The job the plant was used for was started months before, and Barker said that from that time his son would be wholly and solely on his own in everything be did, and the plant would belong to his son. The work being done was the Workhouse extension. I have only seen young Barker twice in my life. Draper prepared the petition and he is the man who misstated the facts, at I thought. I do not remember being put on the deputation to the Local Government Board. As to the Nurses' Home contract, I did not think the expense of putting up the scaffolding was equal to the difference between £45 and £98 15s. Reverting to the indestructible paint, I produce the first certificate to Calcutt at 1s. 6d. which Knight was directed to make. I put my initials to it, "A. W. R." I still say I objected to it. Those things are brought before us the same as the cheques, and we sign them. The only thing I objected to sign was one cheque for Jack
son. The cheque books are slid round three or four at a time, and when one man gets tired of signing he pushes it on to someone else. He goes on signing without looking at what they are. He may sign one he objected to. I objected to Knight taking part in the discus
sions on matters outside his own particular position. In regard to cashing the cheque at Mrs. Key's house, the "King Harry," on No
vember 6, I never had a penny out of it or any other cheque. I did not have champagne there—the statement is absolutely false. I had a glass of wine or a glass of whisky. The purchase of the land for £60 was a bona-fide transaction as far as I was concerned. I deny saying to Stammers (if he was there), "This is a question of paying something to the contractor; not receiving anything from him." The conveyance was not executed till February. I did not take any I O U or receipt for the half price I paid. I had the deeds some little time previous. The deeds were at my solicitor's at the time, and I knew at soon as I got the other £30 paid the conveyance would be com
pleted. It was rather irregular. When I have bought land for a client I have always taken a receipt. I produce my Savings Bank book. I drew £40, out of which I paid the £30 balance and gave £10 to my son. I see by this I did not receive it till February 11. I suppose I must have paid it out of other money. I always had plenty. I was under the impression that I got it out before. The money that I paid on February 6 I must have taken out of my safe. My son, when he gave evidence at the police court, was under the same impression that I was. When I said, on being arrested, "I can name the four wrong 'uns," I referred to Knight, Calcutt, Thacker (our late clerk), and one who is now dead. If Detective Williams had not stopped me I should have gone through the whole of the members of the Board.
Re-examined. I gave notice to the Post Office, at the end of January, to withdraw £40 to pay the balance of the land purchase,

and for some things for my son as I intended, but I spent that. I always had money in my safe. The book shows that the £40 was not paid out till February 11. I then paid the £30 back to my client's account, having used the £30, which I must have done from the safe previously. The Scattered Homes Committee proposed taking No. 473, Mile End Road, to let to the Guardians as a Scattered Home. It was practically taken by the whole of the Board at £65 a year, and I objected and refused to have anything to do with it, and some of my co-defendants here supported me. Barker and Knight both spoke strongly in favour of our taking it, and said we were morally bound. It was then, I think, offered to us at £50, but it stood empty for two years. I cannot recall what happened on January 11, whether I voted or not.

ARCHIBALD THOMAS RIDPATH , "White Horse," Baldock, son of defendant. I assisted my father in his business of estate agent for four years. Calcutt often came to our office in Commercial Road with reference to work he did for us, and I have several times been to Calcutt's office with orders. I saw the title deeds relating to the purchase of land at Leigh which he brought, and they were left in my father's possession for some time. Calcutt came on a date I do not remember, and they talked the matter over. It was the day fixed for the conveyance, and my father took some money from the safe and paid him £30. Calcutt then said, "That is right, Ridpath"—or words to that effect—"that makes the balance of the £60." About a week before I signed the notice to the Post Office of with
drawal. When the warrant for the money came my father kept it. My father fetched the money from the Post Office—I had to sign the application.

Cross-examined. My father did not tell me what the additional £10 was for—one or two things were bought for me. When my father got the money from the Post Office he put it in the safe. This was before February 6. He would not put it with clients' money. We did not talk matters over before I gave evidence at the police court. I reckon we sent in the notice of withdrawal about a week before it was paid. I believe I said at the police court that the money did not come from the London and South-Western Bank, but from the Post Office. I was about to make out a receipt for the money when my father, or Calcutt, said, "Never mind the receipt." My father said, "He has trusted me with the deed, surely I can trust him."

Re-examined. I had not thought the matter over until my father told me on his return from the police court that Calcutt had said he had only paid one £30. I cannot say exactly the date the money came from the Bank.
RICHARD CHARLES HARRY , Clerk in Comptroller's Department, G. P. O., Savings Bank Department, produced the original warrants and withdrawal forms relating to Ridpath's account.
CHARLES ALFRED BAKER , Alderney Road, Stepney. I was Secretary up to Christmas last of the Helping Hand Land Society, which had
an annual sharing out every Christmas. In 1906 Ridpath was a member and contributed 10s. a week. On the sharing out I paid him by cash on December 18, 1906, £23 14s. 10d.

GUSTAV SELIGSOHN , Leigh-on-Sea, house and estate agent. Rid
path instructed me to sell a corner plot of land for him about January last and said, "If you cannot get £60, I will take £50 for it." I did not get a purchaser. At the present time it is not worth that price. The pavement has not been made up. It is a 30-ft. road, I believe, and it would coat about 15s. per foot. That would be between £90 and £100 for road
making on the side. We may have a purchaser any moment.
Cross-examined. Before I had to do with it, I believe it was put up to auction and withdrawn with other plots.
(DEFENCE OF STAMMERS.)

JAMES FREDERICK STAMMERS (prisoner, on oath). I was a licensed victualler for 10 1/2 years at the "Salisbury Arms," Burdett Road. I left in June last and am no longer a publican. I have taken an active part in local philanthropic work connected with the trade. I have known Calcutt since 1898. He came as a customer every day. His wife sometimes accompanied him in the evenings. We became on familiar terms and my wife and I used to visit them when they went to Grafton Street, and he and his wife would often come to our parlour at the back of the bar. Those visits had nothing to do with the business of the Guardians. The visits have been continued since I became a Guardian in 1904. I never heard the expression that I wanted to "join the ring" till Calcutt used it at the police court. I had no object in joining the Board except to serve my fellow citizens. I have never been associated with meetings at the pubulic-house to discuss the business of the Guardians, nor have I heard of them on the part of the other Guardians. Several of the Guardians were customers of mine before I went on the Board. Cal
cutt and I never discussed voting. I never told him I had, or might, vote against him. He came to me and said, "Here, Mr. stammers; this is for voting for me," in regard to anything. He has only said, "Well, if I am in the running; if I am all right, you will support me?" and I have said, "Yes, you have got to take your chance." The two presents he gave me, I thought, came in the way that other things had been given to me by private individuals. I have had many presents given to me. I received a turkey in 1905 and one in 1906, I believe. On one occasion he asked me how I liked the turkey. The turkey was a nice bird, but I am a jocular sort of fellow, and I said, "If you call that a turkey, the next time you send me one make it a fat 'un." He showed me a Masonic charm once that took my fancy. I never asked him for it. I called a Hirst's about midday—I cannot remember the date—and me and Calcutt were the only two in his saloon bar. We had a drink, and he put his hand in his waistcoat pocket and said, "What do you think of that?" I said I did not exactly know the importance of it,

and then he opened it and showed it me. When I saw the engraving inside, being a Mason, I knew exactly what it meant. I said, "That's a splendid thing, isn't it?" "Yes," he said, "it is pretty, isn't it?" So he said, "Will you have it?" I said, "No, thank you, I don't; want it, old man, but it is very pretty." He said, "Go on, you have it." I said, "No," but I ultimately had it, and little did I think it was going to turn corrupt. I knew he was a Mason. It had nothing to do with my voting. The next thing was the candel
abra or mirror which I received from him. There is not a word of truth in Calcutt's account of that transaction. The candelabra was brought round to my place and taken in by my potman and my youngest son, and when I came home it was pointed out to me and I said, "Where did this thing come from?" They were not quite sure about it. My son said, "I believe it was Calcutt that sent it round. A few days after I said to Calcutt," Did you send that candelabra round?" He said, "Yes, don't you like it?" I said, "Yes, it is very pretty, but what did you want to send it round for?" "Oh," he said, "out of friendship. You know very well you done me a good turn once and I cannot forget it." Calcutt had worked for the Guardians long before I got on the Board. I lent him £10 to pay wages when he got a job for the Guardians in succession to Crowe, and that was the "good turn." He repaid it in a few weeks. In 1904 I borrowed two £20, trade being a bit bad. I happened to mention to Calcutt that I was pinched. There are entries in my pass book of £20 and £21 in repayment, on November 5 and De
cember 17 respectively. I cannot account for the odd £1. The third loan was July, 1906 (£20). It was paid into my bank. There is no foundation for saying it was for voting for him. It was on the same conditions as before. It is still owing. I have offered it to him on several occasions, but he would not accept it. I have em
ployed him for a year or two to do odd jobs for me. I had great difficulty in getting an account. I have also supplied him with goods, for which he has not paid. I supplied him with three hampers worth £5 each. The account produced contains an item of £22 9s. for work he did. I should never have thought it would have come to that amount. We had high words about it. It came to £47 odd, and I called his attention to the set-off I have mentioned. I made him out a contra account and receipted it. No money passed. £21 odd would be the balance, apparently, after deducting my contra ac
count. I have no ledger, journal, or day book. Mine was a tied house. I never had £5 from him on July 15, 1905, or £10 on January 15, 1905, or £10 on October 15, 1905, or £20 in January, 1907. In regard to the charge against me of obtaining by false pre
tences, on April 13, £225 13s., I was not present at that meeting and knew nothing about what was likely to occur. The same in regard to £142 4s. 2d. In regard to Calcutt's accounts with the Guardians, I never knew of anything being wrong with them till the Inquiry disclosed it. I was on the Infirmary Committee, the Work-house Committee, and the School Committee. I regarded Knight as a reliable man, having regard to his age and reputation. I have

heard the evidence about the meeting at Spooner's. I took no part in it. I was Treasurer of the Tower Hamlets Philanthropic Society and Trott was Chairman. We went round to get a subscription from Mrs. Spooner. I believe one or two Guardians came in. We didn't stop there more than five minutes. Then me and Trott walked out. I did not see Calcutt. I had nothing to do with Barker's contract. I have never voted corruptly for Calcutt or anybody else.

Cross-examined. I heard Calcutt say that I said, "I am on the Board now, and I want to get in the ring." It is a dream. About three local contractors used my house—Lloyd, Calcutt, and Hasel
tine. Cotterell was a neighbour and regular customer before he became a contractor. Evans is a contractor. There were several contractors to the Board. I had no suspicion, before I became a Guardian, that any of the contractors were getting any money. There is no ground for your suggestion. I took no notice of such sugges
tions which came from outside sources. When I got on the Board I was a keen observer, and to my mind there was nothing of the kind going on. Members of the Board came to my house regularly at customers. They did not meet the contractors there to discuss what business had been done that evening. When I gave my evi
dence before the Inspector, and referred to "a ring of contractors," I did not mean to infer that there was a corrupt ring.
Mr. David. The witness has never used the word "ring" at all. It is a term that is put into his mouth by the interrogator, and not his phrase.
Witness. I meant the old hands—the continuous policy of the Board, as I explained.

(The Solicitor-General put a list of Board meetings to the witness, which he was recorded to have attended, from September 7, 1905, to February 14, 1907.) I do not suggest that I voted against Calcutt on any one of those days, and you cannot prove that I voted for him. Many times I did not vote at all. I voted against him when he had the dining hall contract for £96, and voted for the lowest tender. The gift to me of the mirror may have been in recognition of a kindness I had shown him in 1899. I have never had a penny from him except the three loans. In July, 1906, I sent an old man, Brett, since dead, to Calcutt, to come down. He came with Wallace. What he gave me was a loan, not a gift. He further lies by saying that he went down to the cellar to give it me. It was in the passage. It was three o'clock, and nobody else was there. It was a bona-fide transaction. It has not been repaid, as I have ex
plained. Since this prosecution I have lost my business. I have offered it several times. I never had money from him in the "King Harry." He gave me a turkey, I think, on two occasions, and on one occasion he took away three cases of whisky. I think the settlement between us was March 14, 1907, when I had heard of the Inquiry. It did not strike me that the goods he bought at my house were for other Guardians. I thought the "stuff" was for his own use, seeing that he entertained 20 or 30 people at Christmas. I did not complain to Calcutt and say, "You spend more money at

Hirst's than you do at my place; he gets the 'bunce.'" I do not know what "bunce" means. The Masonic apron was presented to me in Hirst's house in 1906. It is false to say when the £20 loan was handed to me in a banker's bag that I said, "You ought to be more careful than to bring the money down in a bag with a name on it." I did not know he had burnt his books until after the In
quiry. I did not say to him, "It is a good job for some of us that you have burnt your books; they would have shown the game up properly." Referring to the two cheques of £20 and £21, I did not say, "If the worst comes to the worst, Jim, I will say I paid that account with those two cheques, so it will appear I have not lent any money at all—do you see?" I did not go to Southend with my wife and child—my son and wife went down. Barker already had a contract in regard to the school building, which amounted from first to last to about £12, 000. The school buildings had been com
pleted and occupied by September, 1905. This bill to Knight for wines of £30 odd does not refer to the school buildings. Until the prosecution Calcutt and I remained on friendly terms. I cannot suggest any motive for Calcutt turning round and inventing these stories against me.
(Thursday, July 30.)
Mr. Frampton handed in Kemp's pass book showing that there was a payment in on April 22, three days after the cheque of the 20th was taken to Calcutt

JAMES FREDERICK STAMMERS (prisoner, on oath), recalled. Re-ex
amined. When I got on the Board I found there were certain con
tractors who were regularly employed by the Board. In my evidence before the Inspector I said that since I have been on the Board a good many contracts have been given out; the first year I had dealings with the contracts I moved the acceptance of Charrington's tender for coal, because their price was lower, but I was very soon squashed; that was in 1905; and the one thing that weighed with me was that they had been supplying the Licensed Victuallers' Schools. While I was on the Board I tried to apply experience on former Committee for the benefit of the Guardians. I found myself in a minority on other occasions in voting about contracts. I was not upon the Finance Committee at any time.

EDWARD GRIMWOOD , secretary of the Incorporated Society of Licensed Victuallers and of the Licenced Victuallers' Schools. I have known Stammers for nine or ten years as taking an active part in philanthropic institutions connected with the trade. During that time he has been a respected and trusted member of the Committees of those institutions, and has born a good character for integrity and honesty.

Later, evidence to Stammers's character was given by James Hold
ing, fishmonger, 176, Bow Common Lane.
EDWIN RUDGE , borough and sanitary engineer, 264, Burdett Road, Bow. I inspected the work done by Calcutt to a bath and lavatory

Basin in Stammers's house about three months ago. The bath was chipped very badly on the roll; that would affect the value of the bath about 50 per cent. on the original cost. I should think the cost of hoisting that bath from below into its place would be about 10s. The cost of fixing and supplying connections would be about 1s. a foot run for the pipes, of which there is about 10 ft., and 9d. each for three vans—about 16s. or 17s. for the waste; and for the supply, about 27 ft. at 7 1/2 d. per foot; the bath itself is worth about £4. Then to the lavatory basin, there is about 3 ft. of pipe at 1s. a foot, 1s. for the cock, and two vans at 9d. each; that is 6s. 6d. for the waste; the supply pipe is about 7 ft. at 7 1/2 d. per ft.; 9d. each for the two joints, and the basin itself would be worth about 17s.

Cross-examined. I do not know when the bath was chipped. The original value of the bath would be about £4. I should think if all the work charged for in Calcutt's account was done by first-class tradesmen, this charge would still be about £7 or £8 too much.

FREDERICK GEORGE STANTON , builder. In 1905 I was consulted by Stammers about the fixing of a bath which he had in his back yard; it looked as if it had been lying there for some months, and it had a chip off the top rim of the bath. I did the work of the structural alterations of Stammers's house. I did not cut the wall away to get the bath in; we got it through the outside window; we cut a hole through the wall to put the window there. The cost of hoisting the bath would be 10s. or 12s. I was paid for the structural alterations and for putting the bath in position.
Cross-examined. The bath was there in Stammers's back yard when I went to do the other work.

CHARLES SAMUEL NEWSOME , painter. I went to Stammers's house in 1905, where the bath was put up, and did all the painting and de
corating. I was paid by Stammers.

ALFRED PALMER , potman. I was in the employ of Stammers from 1902 till the end of 1904, when I left him; I returned about May, 1905, and remained with him until 1906. About two or three days before Christmas, 1906, I took two cases and a broken case of spirite to Calcutt's house. Mrs. Calcutt told me to take it upstairs, and when I got it upstairs she told me to take it downstairs again into the kitchen. I did that in her presence. In 1905 one of Calcutt's men fetched a hamper away in a trap for the races. I remember seeing a bath in the back yard while I was there, and I afterwards saw it fixed.

Cross-examined. I have often seen Calcutt at Stammers's house. I have also seen Gould and Loftus. I have seen all the Guardians there occasionally. I cannot say that I have seen Kemp there; I may have seen Ridpath, but I am not sure; I am not sure whether I have seen Gilder or Gilson there. Just before Christmas, 1906, is the only time I remember taking spirits from Stammers to Calcutt; I also saw the turkey given. I had seen Hirst there, but not with Calcutt.

Re-examined. Calcutt used to call at the "Salisbury Arms" for refreshments, and Trott also. I knew Loftus to be a relative of Stammers. There was no difference between these men and any other customers who came into the house.

Mrs.
MARY ANN STAMMERS , wife of defendant Stammers. I went to live at the "Salisbury Arms" in 1898. Mr. and Mrs. Calcutt used to come to the house four or five times a week as customers; in course of time we got on friendly terms with them and visited each other. On one or two occasions I called at Calcutt's house in Grafton Street. I remember the Calcutts going to Southend for a change and Calcutt asked me to go there. It is not true to say that I went uninvited, or that I went because I quarrelled with my husband. I went down on a Thursday and returned on the Satur
day morning with Mr. and Mrs. Calcutt. Mrs. Calcutt came up every Saturday to pay the men. Calcutt also asked me if I would let my boy go down and spend a few days with his boys. I was not at great expense while I. was there; I left half a sovereign on the dining-room mantelpiece. I do not remember a mirror coming to the house; I was at Clacton when it came, and some time after it was in the clubroom done up in paper. It was some time after I found out it had come from Calcutt. With regard to the bath, it was in our yard for quite twelve months. I spoke to Calcutt two or three times about sending it away. The last time he was at the saloon bar, and I was at the counter; he came back to me and said, "For God's sake, Mrs. Stammers, don't mention that bath to me any more." He put his two fingers up like that (describing). At last my husband and I arranged to have the club room altered, and the bath put there. I remember hampers being made up for Calcutt on two or three occasions. There is no foundation for the sugges
tion that there has been any misconduct between Calcutt and I or that he has spent money upon me.

Cross-examined. Mrs. Calcutt told us she had no convenience for visitors at Southend. She gave up her own bedroom to me. My son was there a few days. I have known Calcutt nine or 10 years; he was very often in our house, but I have only been to their house once or twice. Calcutt sometimes came to the "Salisbury Arms" with Guardians. We put up the bath because we thought we might as well use it as let it rot.
Re-examined. These gentlemen came to the house as ordinary customers.

JAMES BEARD , shirt manufacturer, 17, Hertford Street, E. I have known Gould for about 20 years; during that time his general repu
tation has been good in every way.

Rev. JOHN FLETCHER PORTER , 51, Cawley Road, Hackney. I am Superintendent of the Hackney and North Bow Missions, and General Secretary of the Primitive Methodists' Orphan Homes. I have known Kemp for some 20 years. His reputation during that time has been that of a trustworthy and reliable man in every way. As far as I could judge, I should not think that they lived beyond their proper means.

Cross-examined. I was informed from time to time what the profits of his business were. He began business first of all on his own ac
count, and afterwards brought in partners.

Rev. LINCOLN STANHOPE WAINWRIGHT , vicar of St. Peter's, London Docks. I have known Warren for about seven years as a fellow member of the Stepney Borough Council, of which he was Chairman in 1906. I have also served with him on the Stepney Distress Com
mittee, of which he has yearly been the Chairman. I have known him as a man of high character, very capable, and very straighfor
ward.
(DEFENCE OF HIRST.)

Rev. WILLIAM JAMES CRYER , vicar of St. Bennett's, Mile End Road;
Rev. PATRICK PALMER , rector of St. Peter's and St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Ilford; Rev. J. F. STERN . minister of the East London Synagegue, Stepney Green; and
Dr. WALTER TURNER , of Bal
ham, were called on behalf of Hirst as witnesses to character.

JAMES BEARD , recalled. In June, 1906. I was walking down the Mile End Road and saw Calcutt standing outside the "Three Crowns" with a horse and trap. I went up and said to him, "Whose lot is this?" He said "It belongs to me. I have taken it for a debt from a friend at Southend. Will you buy it?" I said, "What do you want for it? He said, "I will take £45 from you." I said, "You know I have just sold mine off that cost me nearly £100 for half the money; I don't want it." Then he said, "Do you think Mr. Hirst would buy it?" I said, "You had better ask him." He said, "Well. I think I ought to get a bit more off of him." I said, "You must do the best you can." That ended the conversation. I was present at the Public Inquiry when Calcutt gave his account of the sale of this pony and governess car to Hirst. I understood Mr. Robb's suggestion to be that Calcutt had bought this horse especially for Hirst, the car in one place, the horse in another, and the harness in another. I got up and said, "That is a lie; Calcutt offered it to me for £45." I re
member the election of Guardians in 1904, but I do not remember anything about an election in 1907. It is very likely that I should be in the "Three Crowns" on the night of the election, but I know nothing at all of any conversation between Hirst and Calcutt about giving 5s. to some men.

Cross-examined. I do not remember everything that takes place at a public-house on the night of an election. I should certainly be working hard for the Association. I go into Hirst's house very often; I should never pass the house without popping in to see him. I was with Hirst when he was met at the station by Calcutt's man and the trap. He had come from Herne Bay. We drove away together to Hirst's house. We went in, then Hirst came out and went off in the trap to Leytonstone. I believe he paid £46 for the car; I should think the harness was worth about £5, and the cob about £15. At the Inquiry Calcutt was screening Hirst, giving evidence in his favour. I do not remember Hirst giving a testimonial to Calcutt's

character. I do not remember any conversation at Hirst's house as to whether or not Calcutt should say that he offered the trap to me for £50. I have been 35 years in business; I had a contract for one year with the Guardians for the supply of hosiery—about £100. That is the only tender I ever had. If it is said that I had it two years, on my oath I say I only had it one year, from March, 1906, to March, 1907. There was a small account of about £14 for goods supplied out of contract.

Re-examined. When the Guardians want to make a contract, they usually advertise for tenders, which are sent in on a printed form. I have sent in three tenders, of which only one has been accepted. The £14 was merely an order, not a contract.

ROWLAND HIRST (prisoner, on oath). I live at Wellsfield, Leyton
stone, and am a licensed victualler. I was born in the Mile End Road and am 60 years old. I have had the "Three Crowns" 33 years; it is a very old licensed house. I have also the "Eagle Hotel" at Snaresbrook. I am also interested in "The Bank of Friendship," which is really my daughter's house; I am interested with my brother in the "Colville," King's Road, Chelsea, and in the "Free
mason's Hotel" at Woolwich. I have held six licenses myself at one time. Apart from licensed property, I have a good deal of house property in the neighbourhood of Mile End and at Herne Bay. I have been associated with public life in the Mile End district for about 30 years. I was a member of the Vestry until it was merged into the Stepney Borough Council and for four years Chairman. On the creation of the Borough Council I was elected on that. I was one of the first Aldermen. I was Chairman of the Public Health Committee for the first three years; I was elected Mayor of Stepney in 1904, 1905, and 1906. I am a member of the Metropolitan Asylums Board, Overseer for Wanstead, and a member of the Mile Find Guardians. I first became a Guardian some 20 years ago, and since 1888 I have been a Guardian continuously. I go to the "Three Crowns" every morning at about half-past 10 and stay till about half-past 11; I have an office there in which I generally transact my business. Then I go out generally and get back at about half-past five or six, and stay as a rule till nine or half-past to catch the 9.45 train. The "Three Crowns" is a popular house, and has been used by the members of the Vestry and the Guardians the whole of the time I have been there; it is about 200 or 300 yards from the Guardians' office. I first knew Calcutt about 1900 or 1901; he was in
troduced to me by my brother Robert. I never spoke to him about going in for the Infirmary job. I did not tell Calcutt that he had got the contract. I began to employ Calcutt myself in 1901 to do builders' jobs on my houses. I never received a diamond stud as a present from Calcutt, and Calcutt never, at any time when he gave me a present, said that it was for voting for him, or made any refer
ence to my action on the Board. He gave me a pair of gold sleeve links at Christmas, 1903, at the "Eagle Hotel," Snaresbrook. He said he had come to wish me a merry Christmas; I was shaking hands with him and he put a pair of sleeve links into my hand. I said,

"What are they for, Mr. Calcutt?" He said, "Just a little Christ
mas present." I said, "I don't want them," and he said that he would be very pleased if I would accept them. I said I would much rather not, as I really didn't want them. However, he pressed me, and I said, "Very well, Mr. Calcutt, I won't he rude to you; I will accept them and I will give them to one of my boys." Nothing was said with reference to my action on the Board. In January, 1905, he gave me an umbrella at Mile End; he left it at my Mile End Road house. Some days after that he came in one evening and said, "I left you a little Christmas present, Mr. Hirst," and I said, "Why? I don't want an umbrella, I have a dozen of them now." And so I had Then he gave me a tie pin at Christmas, 1905. That was brought down to the "Eagle" at about 11 o'clock. I should think it was worth about 30s. I was not told that it belonged to the late Lord Angle
sey. I called on Calcutt and told him I thought he was very silly to give me these Christmas presents, and he said, "If you will accept it, I shall be very pleased," so I accepted it and put it in my coat, where it remained until I put it in a safe at my private house, where It remained until the time of the Inquiry. At the time I was arrested I did not know where the pin was, but one Sunday afternoon I found it and took it to the solicitor, who told me to hand it over to Mr. Kane. Then at Christmas, 1906, he sent me a travelling rug to the "Eagle." I never saw that until I saw it in Court. Calcutt never gave me a gold penknife. I thought he gave me these Christmas presents on account of the work he was doing for me; I never thought they had any connection with my action on the Board. With reference to the accounts for the work that he did for me, the repairs amount to £476 4s. 5d. Apart from that he built a house on Lord Tredegar's estate in Harley Street for £478 8s. The next account is one of £43 in 1904 for making good some damage done by fire; then in December, 1907, there is an account of £1 15s. for work done at Bancroft Road, and in August, 1907, £56 for work done partly at the "Freemasons' Arms," and partly at Hertford Street. The amount of work done for me altogether by Calcutt was £1, 055 7s. 5d., which has all been paid for. I never knew he was doing work for me at exceptionally low prices. I sent him to do work wherever I wanted a job done; he did it, and sent in the account, and I never once disputed it with him. With regard to the work done at Bancroft Road, I never had a bill for it, but only a receipt when I paid it. At that time he owed me some money in respect of the Herne Bay houses, and I wrote £30 off that. It is true that Calcutt has bought a substantial number of turkeys from me, and he has also bought wines and spirits at my house. At the end of 1901 there was a slight purchase, and at Christmas, 1902, he gave a considerable order to one of my managers. I said to the manager I thought it was more than Calcutt ought to be buying; it was something like £30; the manager spoke to Calcutt the next morning about it, and he said they always had a large party about Christmas time, and if he did not buy of me he would have to go elsewhere. From that time onward Calcutt has bought a good deal

of wines and cigars from me which have been sold at ordinary prices, and there is a complete record of the transactions in the books. With regard to the turkeys, the first he bought was at Christmas, 1902, 13 turkeys. I have sold turkeys at Christmas time for many years. Calcutt came in one or two days before Christmas Eve, saw the turkeys in the saloon, and asked me if I could let him have a few. I had no idea what he was going to do with them. They cost me about 11d. a pound, and I think I charged him 11 1/2 d. He never told me that he was buying the turkeys for bribes. In 1903 I sold him 12 turkeys at 11 1/2 d. a pound, and one weighing 25 pounds at 1s. 4d. a pound. At Christmas, 1904, I sold him three large turkeys, and at Christmas, 1906, I think, two large turkeys for three guineas. With regard to what has been said about his buying one from me, and send
ing it in my name to Knight, I was sending some turkeys out one night when Calcutt was there; Mr. Knight had been doing one or two little things for me, so I thought I would send him one, and Calcutt said, "I am going that way; I will deliver them for you if you like," and he took them. It went with my compliments to Knight, and it was my present. With reference to the journey to Woolwich in the governess car, I was leaving my Mile End house one afternoon to go to Woolwich and I met Calcutt in the lobby. He said, "I am just going to Woolwich; I have got my horse and trap outside; I will drive you there if you like." I said, "I shall be pleased for you to drive me there." He drove me there and back. On the way back he said, in the Blackwall Tunnel, "This is a nice lot, Mr. Hirst." Nothing more was said about it until we got near the Mile End Road, when he said, "I want to sell this lot." I said, "Do you?" He said, "Yes." When we got to Mile End he said, "Hirst, do you know anybody who would like to buy this?" I said, "No, Calcutt, I do not." Then he said, "Would not you like to buy it?" I said, "No, I have three or four traps of my own, and several horses and a pony, and I do not want any more." Then he said, "Did I know anybody who would buy it?" I said, "No, I do not think so. What did you buy it for?" He said, "I did not buy it; I had to take it for a debt." I told him if he liked to send it down to the "Eagle Hotel" I would see if I could get Mr. Hansell to find him a customer. Hansell is a tenant of mine at the "Eagle Hotel," Snaresbrook. I asked what he wanted for it, and he said £50; then he sent it down to Snaresbrook. After it had been there about a week, Hansell said someone had offered him £45 for it. I told Calcutt and he said he should not take less than £50. Then he tried to persuade me to buy it. He said, "That big horse that you had down at the "Eagle" is too big for you. It would suit me very well. Would you make a deal? You take my pony and trap and have a deal for the horse." I gave him a cheque for £38 and sold him the big horse for £12. I thought that was more than a fair price for the car. Calcutt's account of the transaction, as given in evidence here, is inaccurate. With refer
ence to the houses at Herne Bay, I was just finishing a house in Albany Drive, which Budd was building for me on some land of

my own. Calcutt was down there; he told me hit wife was very ill, and he had been recommended by his medical man to get a house somewhere at the seaside. I said, "Why not build one, you have got some ground there?" He said he should not build on that be
cause he did not like the position, and he asked me if I could sell him a plot to build a house on. I said, "Yes, where would you like it, Mr. Calcutt?" He said, "Somewhere near your farmhouse." We walked down there, and I showed him a piece of ground that I had, and he said he would like to have the corner plot. I said, "Well, you can have that corner site at £1 per foot, and I should think you would want about 30 ft. to build a decent house—a cottage." He said he would talk the matter over with his wife and let me know about it in a few days. About a fortnight later I saw him in my office in Mile End Road, and he asked me what I thought it would cost him to build. I said, "I think you ought to be the best judge of what you want." He said he thought he ought to have a six-roomed villa for something like £300 to £350. He came again in two or three days and said he had been talking it over with his brother-in-law, Mr. Smith' and his wife, and they had come to the conclusion that, if possible, they would like to have a pair of villas. His brother-in-law, Smith, was to have one and his wife the other, as Mrs. Calcutt thought it would be lonely being there alone. He then asked me if I would sell him another 30 ft. of ground and I said, "Yes." I showed him the plan in the office, and he agreed to buy 60 ft. of the ground for £55. I told him I would get a price from Budd for the villas, and the next time I went to Herne Bay I asked Budd to get me out a rough plan for a pair of villas. He sent me a pencil sketch which gave the particulars, to many thousand bricks, etc., and a rough estimate of about £580. I showed that to Calcutt, who approved. I then wrote to Budd. and he commenced, I think, in December, 1905. Calcutt used to call about every fortnight or three weeks and give me what he liked on account of that building. When we had completed the houses, we had spent £564 in wages and material. Then Calcutt wanted some iron railings put in front of each of the houses and a long wall down the side of the road with a pair of carriage gates, and a swing and one or two other things for the children. That extra work cost £56, which was added to the £584. The whole of the money that Calcutt paid me was paid away on the houses. When he paid me the last cheque for £56 4s. 9d. he said, "I am more than pleased with my houses; I certainly think we ought to make Mr. Budd a present," and he said he would write to Mr. Cordys and Mr. Lloyd, who had the houses built adjoining. He said he thought they ought to give Budd a present of £20, out of which he said, "I shall be quite pleased to give £10 myself, and I think Mr. Lloyd and Mr. Cordys would be also willing to give £5 each." I said if they gave him a present of something he could look at, it would be more pleasant than money, and Calcutt said he did not care which way it was, so I suggested a watch, and the watch was bought and presented to him. I think Calcutt went into occupa
tion of the house in July, 1906. and stayed there some three or four

months. No complaint was ever made to me that the houses were not properly finished. Calcutt's account of this matter is not correct. At about this time I bought "The Bank of Friendship" public-house in Mile End. It was in the hands of Receivers when I bought it and the occupier had some furniture. I said to him, "Well, I shall not want this furniture." Then the thought struck me that Calcutt, having to furnish his house at Herne Bay, it would be useful to him. I sent across for Calcutt and showed him the furniture in the room with the manager's figures; I think the manager agreed to sell the whole of the furniture in that room for £34, or £39, I am not sure which. I paid for it and Calcutt repaid the same amount to me. I put no sort of pressure on him to buy it and made no profit on it. I did not at any time know that Calcutt had hired carriages for the use of my canvassers at the election. I know he had none of his own which he could lend out. I recollect the witness Da Costa; I saw him on the morning of the polling day in 1904. He either told me that he was going to vote or had voted for me. I saw him in the evening at the "Three Crowns" with Calcutt and one or two others. I had no conversation with him and never promised him a "spread." I did not know that he had been going about Mile End in a carriage for me that day. I never gave 5s. to Calcutt to give to the driven of the hired carriages, telling him they were not to know where it came from. The truth about that matter is this. It was not on the polling day, but either before or since; I had been to the West End one evening and I came up to Mile End Road. I wanted to pay the cab
man. The fare was either four or five shillings, and Calcutt happen
ing to be there I said, "You might pay the cabman," and I handed him those two blackened half-crowns. I said, "Don't give him those two half-crowns, but you might give him 5s. of your own money." With regard to the meeting at the "Three Crowns," the Board meet
ings are on Thursday nights and there are Committees on Tuesday nights; on those occasions a good many of the Guardians would drop in after the meetings. That made no difference to the time I went home. I would sometimes come out of my office into the saloon bar and see them there, but I never heard any talking about how contracts should be dealt with. I never saw dozens and dozens of bottles of champagne being drunk and never saw Calcutt standing champagne round. On one night in March, 1906, there were several of the contractors there, and I did see several bottles of champagne, but I do not think one was paid for by Calcutt. There were several of the Guardians, and many friends of the various contractors. I left at 9.30; I do not know how long they stayed. With regard to the conversation with Calcutt and Haseltine in 1904, I deny the whole conversation, and with regard to the whitewashing of the Infirmary in 1903, when Calcutt says that he and Knight discussed their rival claims before me, that conversation never took place, and I did not say to Calcutt, "Look here, what a fool you were not to stick out; you would have got another £30." I remember Calcutt coming to my house on the day that I had been up to give evidence about my books

at the Inquiry. I said to him, "I am very sorry to hear, Calcutt, you have destroyed your books. I have just been up there with mine. If you had taken up yours as I have taken mine, you would not be in the trouble you are in." Calcutt's account of that con
versation is not correct. With regard to the conversation about the granolithic paving to the Workhouse entrance, at that time I was Chairman of the Workhouse Visiting Committee; we had been round on a survey in the afternoon and I met Calcutt in the grounds. I told him the Committee were going to recommend the Board to pave the path to the Master's house and in due course he would have par
ticulars from the Surveyor. That is all. With regard to Barker's contract. I never heard Calcutt telling Barker that his son was to get certain contracts on giving certain of the Guardians £300. My actions on the Board have never been influenced by any motive resulting from anything Calcutt had given me. A search is being made in the books of the Guardians in respect to all my votes since 1898. Some of my votes have been in support of Calcutt and some against him. Every
thing I have ordered in regard to the Scattered Homes would appear above my signature in the books. I was on the Committees from 1904, but during my Mayoralty I could not attend very much. I always triad to attend the Board meetings on the relief cases. Up till 1903 the jobbing work was done simply under Knight. If there was a difference between Knight and Calcutt I should have supported whichever I thought was right. If there was a dispute, Knight would take the accounts back and bring them up at the next Committee meeting. Then the Committee would recommend that he should try and arrange with Calcutt; then at the next meeting Knight would tell the Com
mittee that he had arranged with Calcutt for so much, and we would pass the account. With regard to the Arbitration Committee, after Knight had put his case to the Committee and pointed out that his price was the correct one, I agreed with him to certify for £371. I do not think I was present when it came back to the Board. I think on the Committee Mr. Andrews and myself voted for Knight and the other members of the Committee voted for Calcutt. In re
gard to the taking of No. 1, Bancroft Road, Calcutt offered his house and yard for £150 a year. I proposed an amendment that the house only should be taken at a rent of £60 per annum. After the voting Thacker said the Local Government Board had already refused it. I should think £65 was a proper rent. With regard to the tenders in which I actually voted for Calcutt, I knew Calcutt had always up to that time done his contract work well, and I supported him on those grounds. As a rule, if we got anybody in the Borough, or anybody that was near, we would support them in preference to people outside the Borough. When the Inquiry commenced, I volun
teered, through my solicitors, to give all the information I could. I have taken up that position throughout, and all the documents I ever had are available.

Cross-examined. I said nothing at the Inquiry about the gold cigsr case; I was not asked about it, nor about the tie-pin, the gold sleeve links, the gold and ivory-handled umbrella, the travelling rug,

or the gold watch that was presented to Budd. I was never asked about those things, and they never crossed my mind. I have always tried to do the best I could for the ratepayers. I do not know that I stood on any particular programme advocating the strictest pos
sible regulations for securing impartiality and purity in contracting. The house, No. 5, St. Helen's Terrace, was acquired from me on lease in 1903 at a yearly rent of £60. I think it was in good re
pair at that time. I have heard since that £97 was spent upon it the first year. I do not know what it was spent for. I should think for ordinary wear and tear £15 would have been sufficient. It was let at £65 before I let it to the Guardians. I am not aware that it was inspected by Knight before I completed my arrangement with the Guardians. I do not remember a resolution in September, 1900, to the effect that no house should be taken from a member of this Board or a member's wife, or any relation of a member of this Board. I do not think I should have supported a resolution of that kind. My personal policy was to restrict the acceptance of tenders to those who lived within the Borough. Mr. W. A. Barker's works were in the Borough. He carries on business at his fathers place; I believe he lives at Forest Gate. I believe he built a temporary hospital for small-pox patients in 1904, but I do not remember whether I advo
cated the acceptance of his tender. I was Chairman, of the meeting. It was done as an emergency on account of the small-pox epidemic; young Barker was doing another contract on the premises, and we asked him to tender for it, and it was got on with immediately. Mr. George Barker is a neighbour of mine at Leytonstone, and he was a member of the Board. If the son had a contract and his father, being a Guardian, lent him the plant, I should not see any harm in that. I do not recollect having any conversation with Barker, sen., upon the question of giving the contracts to his son. Barker, jun., also had a contract under the Board under which he was paid £7, 000 or £8, 000.
Mr. Vachell objected to the cross-examination as being on totally new ground, which was not put before the magistrate.
The Solicitor-General said it could not be put before the magistrate because Mr. Hirst did not there offer himself as a witness.

Mr. Justice Phillimore. In abstaining from offering himself as a witness before the magistrate he was quite within his rights; but when he starts the case here, which was not expected by the Crown, he must be prepared to meet the cross-examination.

The tender of William Barker for the old school buildings was £9, 447; there were six lower tenders, and the highest was £14, 000 I supported Barker because I knew that if he had got this tender he would employ local labour, and at that time there was a lot of distress about. I do not recollect that I moved on January 12, 1905, that additional works should be executed by Barker to the extent of £3, 746. (The minute was read.) There is no doubt that is correct. The whole of this work would be under the supervision of Knight. I may have voted on June 30, 1904, for another £530 in connection with the old school buildings. The document produced gives Barker's address as Settles Street, Commercial Road; that is his father's ad
dress;

I do not know whether he had another place. The signature is "W. A. Barker." I see the letters "Geo" there. I do not remem
ber seeing that before. I have no doubt I said at the Inquiry that I supported him partly because he was the son of Mr. Barker; I should think that probably would be so. It is very likely that the Guardians spent £17, 000 less last year than they did the year before, considering the large amount of work that had been done in the earlier year. I do not know what the estimate for this year is. I have not seen it. It is impossible that the rates can have been reduced by 1s. 1d. With regard to the governess car and cob, I should say there is nothing special about it. The first suggestion as to the sale of it came through Calcutt and not from me, and also the suggestion of an exchange for my big horse. If I said differently at the Inquiry it was wrong. I am on oath now, and I swear that the account I have given to-day is the right one, that Calcutt told me he had taken it for a debt. I did notice at the time that he had his monogram on the harness, but that is very easily put on. The harness was not new, but it was in very good condition. Calcutt did not say to me, "I would not sell it to anybody else but you for £50." I consider that I gave the full value for it. I daresay the cob now is worth £25 or £30; it has considerably improved since I had it, I think I said at the Inquiry it was worth £30. When I had it it was not worth £15. It is about seven or eight years old now. I was asked in Sep
tember, 1907, whether I would, sell the lot for £50, and I said, "No." I think I paid £10 a little while ago to have it repaired. The value of the trap in September, 1907, would be about £20, and the harness £6 or £7.
(Friday, July 31)

ROWLAND HIRST (prisoner on oath), recalled. Further cross-examined I now produce the demand notes as to the reduction of rates. There is no reduction this quarter. I used to attend to this matter, but my memory is gone from me now. I was a supporter of Barker's contract for the Nurses' Homes, of December 22, 1904. He did not give a champagne dinner at my house that night. On January 12, 1905, I knew of some disturbance about the matter, and that young Barker offered to withdraw. I had not heard from old Barker anything about the Guardians deriving some benefit from that contract. I think I have some recollection of moving on February 9, 1905, the acceptance of the tender. I forget all about it now. On December 22 W. A. Barker got the contract. The next day a memorial was sent in to the Local Government Board. I was in favour of the building of the Nurses' Homes by anyone. I was chair
man of the Infirmary Committee for years, and it was constantly before the Committee—the advisability of making suitable accommodation for the nurses. It did not matter to me who built it. I believe it was knocked on the head altogether; it has not been built up to now. I fancy I have some recollection of a reply of Barker's to Mr. Draper at the discussion. "It is the fact that all the plant upon the job belongs to me, and has my name and address upon it. But cannot I lend my plant to my son?" I think I said if I had got a son doing a building job, or any
thing

else, I should lend him all I had. I do not think there is any harm in that. On February 14 I moved that young Barker should have the contract without any tenders being invited. That was on account of the small-pox epidemic. I have no recollection of all this now. Of course, you cannot go from the minutes; they must be correct. For the last twelve months my memory has been absolutely a blank. I do not think I was appointed on a deputation which might have to wait on the Local Government Board. I do not recollect Draper again moving on May 7, 1905, that nothing be done in connection with the Nurses' Homes. I was first mortgagee of the Freemasons' Hotel at Woolwich, and the man that was in possession had to get out at very short notice, and I wanted someone to temporarily hold the license for me. I met young Barker, and I took him over to the Bench at Woolwich, and told the Bench the case, and they temporarily granted the license to Barker. I think I can find the evidence for that. Young Barker did it merely to oblige me. This temporary transfer I suppose lasted six or seven months until I found a tenant. It was a regular transfer, but I explained it to the Bench because they tem
porarily transferred it to him. I did not think it was as long as from June, 1905, to November, 1907, that he held the license. I am in a fear
ful nervous state. I do not know what I am saying. I do not deny it, but it does not seem possible. I think Long succeeded him. I let it to him on a tenancy agreement. He was originally one of my managers. If Barker had any business he could carry it on just the same. He used to go over to the public-house now and again, perhaps once a week. I can
not tell you what other business he did. I do not know that he never did a single job. The nurses were provided with accommodation of a sort. I never went over it. I did not know that the cost to the Guardians after Barker's contract was knocked on the head was £1, 000. A pair of sleeve links was presented to me, and I put my initials on them. During the Inquiry I brought the sleeve links out and showed them to Mr. Robinson and one or two others at the saloon, and Harris the jeweller was in the bar at the time. He said "Shall I have these cleaned up for you and have your initials put on them?" I asked him to do so. That was only quite recently. I never used them. I thought the pin was worth about 30s. I put it in my coat for about three months. I put it in the safe. I never had a gold penknife. I gave a gold penknife to Calcutt to be repaired. That is in Court now. My son has it. It was bought in Paris at the Exhibition. Calcutt happened to be there, and he told me he knew some one who could repair it. I paid him 2s. 6d. for having it repaired. I believe it has got the French stamp on it. There was a whip in the trap when I bought it—when I bought the horse. I think it was a whalebone whip. That was part of the trap. My brother Bob works for the Stepney Borough Council in the engineer's department and does some general work in the office. He is a plumber by trade. He introduced Calcutt to me. I think that was about 1900 or 1901. I have no recollection of the contract for £594. I never advised Calcutt to go in for it. I never spoke to him; he had not been to my house to my knowledge. I should not call him a constant customer since. He did not for years after that buy wine and spirits of me to the extent of over £100 a year. I should think about £30 to £40

a year. In regard to the question put to me at the Inquiry as to Calcutt having paid me £124 for wine, spirits, &c., in the course of 12 months, I withdraw my answer to that, because the next day we went through the accounts and we found it worked out at £30 a year. Whatever the amount was it was in addition to anything he bought and paid for in the house. I used to give turkeys to different friends at Christmas time. I have a lot of relations. I suppose I sent away 15 or 16 to them. Out of 40 turkeys Calcutt bought about 13 and the balance I sold. For the last two or three years I have not bothered with them at all. I remember Grimes coming on the Board. I did not advise Calcutt to split his customers between me and Grimes. I did not know that Grimes was supplying Calcutt with turkeys. I heard some one say so in evidence, and I said he could not have done because I had supplied him that year with 20. That is what I said, but the biggest number he ever bad from me was 13. I only got that information from the Inquiry. I think I explained last night that I told Calcutt, to whom I was giving these turkeys, that I was going to send one to my private house and one to the "Eagle" at Snaresbrook, and Calcutt said "I am going that way—to Leytonstone. If you do not mind I will take them." So I (said "With pleasure." So he took them. I knew that Calcutt had a piece of land at Herne Bay. I do not know whether there were three or four plots. When Calcutt first spoke to me about building the houses at Herne Bay I mentioned his own plots to him. He said he did not care to build the houses there for himself, but he would ultimately build for someone else on those plots. He did not like the position. He chose the plots not built on. I was going to build him one house and he chose the corner plot in the Blackburn' Road. I took him down there after he had said he would not build on his own plots, and I showed him what I had got and he selected this corner plot. I had got a piece of thirty-seven plots. I had a farmhouse there. The place where the houses are built might be a mile, at the outside, from the sea. There was not a single house there other than the ones I built for the contrac
tors. There are many houses round about there. The whole lot of ground was sold in plots. I bought one piece of twenty-seven plots. There had been no other houses built in that road. I never tried to tell any of it. The land is still vacant. The only plots sold were the ones to Calcutt, the one to Cordy, and one to Lloyd. Cordy was a tradesman—not a contrac
tor to the Mile End Board. Lloyd is a contractor for milk. I do not remember admitting at the Inquiry that Lloyd from the year 1902 onward had had £800 more than would have been paid to the lowest tenderer. I think he has been the milk contractor all the years that I have been on the Board of Guardians. I do not know that in each of those years other people had tendered at lower sums. I know Lloyd always used to get the contract year after year. We only used to go by the figures; it would be 10d. or 10 1/2 d. per gallon. We should not know how much would be con
sumed. I do not think different people tendered at lower rates. I have not read the report of the Inspector after the Inquiry that I recollect. I did not know that there had been tenders every year from 1902 without a break to 1908 of £120 to £150 lower than Lloyd. We used not to get it in that way but at per gallon. It might make a farthing difference, or something like that.

Mr. Justice Phillimore. It may be summed up in this way. In fact you made Lloyd a present of £868 during the past seven years through not accepting the lowest tenderer. What is the explanation of that? Your answer is, "The explanation so far as I know is, we always had good milk—we never had a complaint about Lloyd."

Witness: In regard to the houses at Herne Bay I only know from what I heard from Budd, when he was up there the other day, that they were all let. I do not live in Herne Bay and I have not been there for four or five months. My house is on the front. When I am there I stick there. I never lived in a farmhouse. When the question was put to me at the police court I did not recollect Mr. and Mrs. Calcutt ever staying there with me, but Mrs. Hirst has told me that they did. They stayed there from Satur
day to Monday one night in August. That was on account of Mrs. Calcutt wanting to go down and see houses at Herne Bay. I invited them myself. I do not know about Calcutt being uneducated. I took a fancy to him, and I used to put him forward as much as I possibly could. I was invariably kind to him. In regard to the cost of the houses, I showed him all the bills, with the exception of the small accounts that Budd had said he lit the fire with and Budd's book. I had the bills for all the timber and bricks and all the heavy goods, ironmongery, and so on. The account is roughly in that book. I made the account out for him. I showed him the amount of money paid for bricks, showed him the number of cheques I sent Budd for wages account, what I paid for timber, and so on, and they came to what I had charged him. He had them all out on the day of settlement, and took them away with him. This book was never produced in any proceedings until now. Calcutt saw it. It was never in dispute. I only used to keep rough notes of these accounts. It was really put down in the banking account. It is the whole transaction. The furniture in the "Bank of Friendship" was taken down to Calcutt's house. My sister wanted it, but I preferred his having it. Bourchier, the carpenter and builder, knew six or eight weeks before the houses were finished that they were for Calcutt. I paid him right up to the finish. In 1903 there was the whitewashing contract, on which Calcutt claimed £503. Knight certified for £371 and Calcutt was paid £440. I do not think Knight said £503 was a "terrible price," but he did accept the phrase. I never said to Calcutt, "If you had stood out for another £30 you would have got it." I agreed with Knight that £373 was right. Mr. Andrews and myself, on the Select Committee, opposed the payment. We were out-voted on the £371 or £373. I do not recollect whether I took any steps at the Board meeting to prevent Calcutt getting the £70 extra. I don't think I was there, or, if I was, I had very likely left before it came on. In regard to the indestructible paint, there also I said I thought Knight's was the proper amount. I supported Mr. Kirwen when he moved the 9d. at the Board. I was there and voted, but I was Mayor then, and had to get away to a meeting after. I never had any communication with Mr. Draper about it. I do not know much of him. He has been on the board eight years. I should think I voted against Calcutt on many occasions. I cannot name any, or when I voted for him. On July 18, 1907, Calcutt was the highest of all who tendered for the Scattered Hon es, but that was only a bit of frivolity. There was a little

frivolity—the same as I have heard in this court—because Calcutt was more than double. I, or someone else, said "I move Calcutt," but I voted for Herbert. It was taken as "I vote for Calcutt" I have heard since, but it was never so intended. I did not move the resolution on July 18. I voted on February 14, 1907, for the granolithic pathway. Draper moved as an amendment that the work be done by the Guardians' own labour. I voted against that, and moved that Calcutt's offer be accepted for £38 10s. for painting the Isolation Hospital. I supported Calcutt because I thought it a very fair price. On the same day I voted for Calcutt's tender for repairs to 64, Tredegar Square of £68 15s. as against Newton and Brown. Up to 1903 Calcutt had done the work with no scale of prices. Knight had certified what he thought right. Then it was ordered that there should be a scale of prices tendered for. I never saw the schedule. I do not think tenders were invited for painting the Infirmary. It got the sanction of the Local Government Board. I never went into the Infirmary while that work was being done. At the finish it went into £2, 000 or £3, 000. Haseltine is not a particular friend of mine. I have known him for twenty-five or thirty years. With regard to Knight's statement that I told him Mr. Robb would not have much difficulty in proving that money had passed between "these people" (some of the Guardians) and Calcutt, I deny that I said anything of that sort. I can't suggest a reason for Knight inventing a story of that kind. It never came out of my mouth. I never heard any suggestion that the Guardians were benefiting by contracts until the Inquiry. I remember, on February 6, 1906, entertaining Ridpath and Calcutt at the "Ship and Turtle." There was no discussion about Guardians. I asked them if they would join me in a little lunch. We had an ordinary lunch and I paid for it. I have done that frequently to Ridpath and Calcutt and others. I can only sug
gest as a reason for Calcutt saying what he has about me that he asked me to stand bail for him and I refused. Up to that time he and I were on friendly terms. That was before he pleaded guilty. I could not have thought he was guilty. I refused to stand bail on account of my position as Mayor of Stepney. I supported Haseltine's contracts for supplying vegetables when I found him reasonsble. I don't think I ever voted against him. I did not know till recently that he was an undischarged bankrupt. I do not recollect Gilson having a contract for meat for the Scattered Homes. The bread contract was given to Maycroft. I have heard about Marble since the inquiry. I understood that Marble supplied Maycroft and Maycroft supplied it to the Workhouse. Marble was a member of the Board.

Re-examined. The first contract placed with Barker, junior, was for something like £8, 000. I did not obtain the value of a pin's head through it going to him. If the contract for the Nurses' Home had gone through it would not have been any advantage to me. [Resolution of March 23, 1905, read. ] The complete list of tenders referred to would show exactly the amounts at which tender was sent in and the names. At the end of the Inquiry the Inspector said, "There are no serious allegations against Mr. Hirst at all." The Inspector shook hands with me on my leaving the box. I have since yesterday procured some of the demand notes for rates in respect of three months. [Handed. ] When the license was transferred

it was in the name of Barker, junior. He slept a few times on the premises I think. He went there about once a week. The manager was the responsible person. I had no idea what Calcutt was going to do with the wines and spirits. They were never supplied by me direct. I had no idea what was going to be done with the turkeys. It was on Calcutt's own suggestion that he purchased the land at Herne Bay. I was not interested in any way. I had a lot of land there and several houses. He did not say that he would rather have the houses built on his own land. He did not like the plots he bought for himself. The account in that book of moneys expended in buildings shows I am to the good. The date of all those cheques is in the books; they are all round figures. I used to send him £20, £30, or £40 for wages and outgoings. I voted with Knight on the matter of tiling round the sinks, 1, Bancroft Road, I remember Calcutt wanted £150, I moved a resolution to take the house as it stood at £65. I remember the Isolation Hospital vote (£38 10s.). I moved the acceptance of that as I thought it a very reason
able charge. On February 6, 1906, Ridpath and I had been to order an illuminated address to Alderman Warren, and on our way back we met Calcutt and asked him to the "Ship and Turtle," where I treated him to lunch. Budd was building houses for me as well as for Calcutt. I agreed to build them for £300 each. I think Budd was regularly employed by me for about two years building, 1904-5-6. I produce the cheques I gave Budd and my pass book. That the sums I have charged against Cal
cutt refer only to the building of his house is shown by the total of Budd's book, and then I gave him a cheque for the odd money at the finish—£27, I think. The book came to be at my house, when found by the police, because Budd sent it to me, at the completion of the work, three or four months ago.

WILLIAM EDWARD DAVIS , John Street, Adelphi, surveyor and architect: I have had 31 years' experience—the last 15 1/2 on my own account. For about 10 years I was assistant to Evans and Deacon, of Adelaide Street. I have examined the figures in there accounts said to have been delivered by Calcutt to Hirst for repairs done for Hirst to his different properties, and inspected the properties, except "The Woolpack" and another house where it was merely an estimated amount. There was some work at Herne Bay included in these also. Wherever it was possible to form an estimate I have put down the value in the left hand margin in red. On the right are Calcutt's charges. Some figures I have put in my account in green ✗mk items that it was very difficult to trace. I have accepted Calcutt's figures in those cases. At the end of my account I have made a summary. My valuation is £327 0s. 9d. and Calcutt's account against that is £337 6s. 5d. There is no case where, I think, he has undercharged. It is a progressive increase up to page 19, where there is a slight difference in his account. The work is done in about the cheapest way possible. My valuation is rather more than Calcutt's charge, but I have put in my figures because that is the basis of the valuation through the account and the manager said he had had the work done for the price charged.

Cross-examined: I supplied this before the commencement of the trial. I have the originals on which I made my calculations. [Produced. ] There is very little difference in the price of that class of work as to the time

when it was done. In one case my note is "Tennant says most digging was done by Parish Authorities when searching for sewer"; but the cost of digging is allowed in my estimate. The amount of items impossible for me to trace is £41 4s. 5d. I was not asked to see and value any of the work done for the Guardians.

HY. PETTMAN , 15, High Street, Herne Bay, architect and surveyor: I have had fifteen years' experience of the building trade in Herne Bay. My father was a builder there and I was brought up in the business. I have had special experience in estimating for builders' work and a very large percentage of work done in Herne Bay during the last four years I have estimated. On May 29 last I examined the two houses of Calcutt's in Blackburn Road. Budd handed me the plans. I had nothing to do with the erection of those houses, nor had I seen them before. I estimated what it would cost to erect them in 1906. In the absence of specifications I measured off the quantities. The probable cost of erection would be about £700.

Cross-examined: My valuation is as near cost price at possible. The builder would probably add a profit to that. My figure is without builder's profit. If he were cutting for the job he would probably put it in at that price. I knew nothing of the circumstances of the job I have never seen or spoken to Hirst. It is not usual always to have a specification. I asked for one. I found there had been no architect, and I did not include his fees, nor did I reckon for a quantity surveyor. The value of the two houses to-day, including the land, if £750. Herne Bay property is not paying now more than about 5 per cent. I should not ex
pect more for freehold property. I was only called upon to value the one block, known as Calcutt's. There was one house in that block occupied, I think. I did not ask the rent. I think they would be worth more than 7s. 6d. a week—about 8s. or 9s. each £20 a year. The insides of the houses were perfectly dry, the joinery is of fair quality, the slates, fittings, and finishings were of medium quality. They are six-room houses with bath-room and scullery, semi-detached. They were put up to auction a short time ago, the highest bidding being £280.

Re-examined. The £280 would be for one house. There was no bidding when the two were put up. The auctioneer did not declare them sold. There is very often a great difference between the money you spend on building a house for yourself and the price you get for it when you want to sell it. I have heard it said that "fools build houses and wise men live in them." I was not ask to inspect the other block.

AGNES HILL , 72, King's Road, Chelsea, wife of Frank Hill: I was manageress for Hirst, of the "Three Crowns" Hotel, from July, 1901, until October, 1903. My husband was the manager. I am keeping another house for Hirst now. I knew Calcutt as a customer. The Guardians used the house on Tuesdays and Thursdays. While I was there I never sold Calcutt a bottle of champagne. He would come sometimes twice a week, or three times, in the mornings and on Saturday evenings with his wife. At Christmas, 1902, I sold to Calcutt large quantities of wines and spirits. It was an exceptionally large order, and when brought to the notice of Hirst he came out into the bar and said, "What on earth is Mr. Calcutt having all this stuff for?" I said he has

large parties and they use it all at home, and they each pay their share. I got that information from Calcutt. I used to speak very friendly to him. On that occasion I looked in on the party at his house just after twelve at night. There were between twenty and twenty-five people, and the stuff that we went round I saw being consumed in the house. Hirst used to leave the "Three Crowns" between 9.20 and 9.30 p.m.

Cross-examined. Calcutt got nothing from us at Christmas, 1901. The bill at Christmas, 1902, was £30. I keep the weekly account, but not the stock book; my husband keeps that. Perhaps six or seven of the Guardians would come into the "Three Crowns" every Board meeting day, or perhaps only two or three. I do not think any of the defendants. I have Been Loftus, Mr. Gunter, and Trott. I do not know much of the other gentlemen. There was not much drinking going on when they came in after the meeting. There was not any more jollification on contract nights than on other nights—just a little. I would know it was contract night by there being more Guardians there. I did not always know the contractors. I know Haseltine. He usually came there on contract nights. I know Cordy, he was not always there on contract nights. Lloyd did not use the house so much while I was there. I never opened more than two quart bottles of champagne for Haseltine while I was there. That was on a contract night. None for Lloyd. The two bottles would be shared amongst the Guardians. I have never served Calcutt. He never came in with the Guardians. In my time he only came in in the mornings, and very little with the Guardians. He might have stood beer to the Guardians in the mornings. I could not swear he was not there on contract nights. He usually had two boxes of cigars, 18s. the two. Perhaps once in two months and perhaps it would go for six months. December, 1902, contract read," 18 bottles Irish whisky, 18 bottles sloe gin, 12 bottles port, six of champagne, six of brandy, six of gin, 100 Murias, 600 Rothschilds, 150 separate cigars.
