"I do not know about them being served loose, we always served them out in boxes. We did not supply goods to Haseltine to take away from the premises, or to Lloyd or Cordy. I was at the "Coborn" in King's Road, Chelsea (one of Hirst's houses) from October, 1903, till the Inquiry. We have been at the "Coborn" with Hirst for seven years. I took my sister and sister's young man to Calcutt's house on the Christmas night. I never saw the champagne.

EDWARD STIMPSON LONG , "Freemason's Hotel," Station Road, Wool
wich. I was manager of the "Three Crowns" from October, 1903, to August, 1905, and after that from November, 1906, to September, 1907. I knew Calcutt very well. He generally came to the house on Board nights, not much during the week. I saw most of him on Tuesday evenings and Thursdays. Most of the Guardians came there on those evenings and used the saloon bar. Calcutt's usual drink in the evening was a 'glass of beer. I have served them about half a dozen times with champagne—quart bottles. They do not hold quite a quart. I have served him at the most with three. They would be drunk by the people in the saloon at the time. They pretty well always stood champagne in their turn. We charge 10s. a quart bottle. Hirst was not with the general company much, he generally went away early in the evening—he would call in about seven.

Calcutt has said something about standing dozens and dozens of cham
pegne. There is no truth in that in my time. It is not true that he was the only person who stood champagne. The others were Loftus, Gilson, Kemp, Haseltine, Cordey, and Lloyd. One would stand one bottle, and one another—it went round in finger-glasses.

Cross-examined. Champagne was not always going round on contract nights. I only remember two occasions. I knew contract nights from other people saying "Those people there are the Guardians having a drink on contract nights." I think Stammers stood champagne, and Mr. New
port, Mr. Lloyd, Kemp, Loftus, and Hirst himself stood six. There were about 13 or 14 bottles stood that night. The drinking was kept up about two hours. It would be about two years ago, about April I should think. From 1903 to 1905 there were similar transactions going on. April, 1904, was the other occasion. I know George Barker who was a great friend of Hirst's. I have seen him in the house. I have not seen young Barker with the Guardians on those nights, but I have seen him with the Guardians at other times. The three bottles of champagne on January 18, 1904, would be to take away. Haseltine was a greengrocer. I do not think he is a Mile End man. I think I have supplied Lloyd with cham
pagne, which was consumed outside. The handwriting in the corner of that page of the ledger is Mr. Hirst's. It is before my time. I went to the "Freemasons'" as licensee. The manager formerly was Harris. There was no tenant. Harris was the leaseholder. Young Barker was the tenant immediately before me. When I was at the "Freemasons' Arms" I got into some trouble. I had a conviction for drunkenness on the premises and had to give up the license.
Re-examined. When Hirst provided six bottles it was the Guardians' election. I do not know Da Costa.

MABEL AUCKLAND . My husband is now manager of the "Three Crowns" for Hirst. I was there from July, 1905, till Novem
ber, 1906, with my husband. I knew Calcutt as a customer. Some
times be would come in twice a week and sometimes once a fort
night—sometimes with the Guardians. He usually had a glass of bitter. He never bought dozens of bottles of champagne. I have known him pay for champagne once or twice, and other people.

Cross-examined. There was very seldom champagne drunk on Guar
dians' nights. There was once, on contract night I heard it was. Mait
land paid for four bottles. Newport and Gunter and several others.—Hirst, Loftus, Ridpath, Gilder, and Trott—were there. Calcutt stood three or four bottles at 10s. Maitland, I think, stood five. Hirst did not stand any.
Re-examined. Hirst would be in his private office at the back usually. The "Three Crowns" is near where the Guardians lived.

THOMAS STANLEY FENTON , General Ironmongery Stores, Mile End Road. Hirst is a customer of mine and I supplied him with ironmongery for some of the houses at Herne Bay. I was there when a presentation was made to Budd of a gold watch. Calcutt was there and he said they had got up the presentation for the excellent way in which the work had been done, and they were dividing the cost between the three who owned

the houses, and he thought about giving him £20 but that the others objected. I said, "What, are you as a builder, going to allow Mr. Hirst to build for you?" He said, "If I had built them myself with my men it would have coat me £150 more than I am paying for them."

Cross-examined. I went to Herne Bay two or three times to get orders for material. My account was £50 or £60, rendered and paid at the time by Hirst. I haven't it with me. I was present with Calcutt, Hirst, Lloyd, and Budd at the presentation. My first tender was on March 25 last. Previous to that I had supplied ironmongery, but not under con
tract. I was first spoken to about this matter after the Inquiry. I volunteered.
To the Court. Hirst did not subscribe to the presentation. He was asked to present it on behalf of these people.
(DEFENCE OF TROTT.)

GEO. ALLEN , 150, Skidmore Street, Mile End, master plasterer. I have known Trott about ten years as a very honourable, hardworking, upright man. I know Calcutt. I went to Southend on one occasion with Trott and our wives. We met Miss Calcutt on the front with another young woman. We lunched at Mrs. Calcutt's. We met Mr. Calcutt coming out of the station about two o'clock and we went into the "Middleton" and had a drink. Calcutt took us out in the back and showed us a cart, and said, "What do you think about that?" I said, "It is a nice thing." He told the man to fetch out a horse, and said, "You had better come for a drive." We were rather surprised, but said, "All right." Some
thing was said about there not being room for us, and Calcutt got a landau and we went, I think, to Hockley. Something was said about payment and Calcutt said, "That is all right, everything is settled." I was there on another occasion when Trott spent the day with me and I met Calcutt in the evening accidentally.

WALTER TROTT (prisoner, on oath). I have lived in Mile End all my life and have known Calcutt from a lad. He was a customer of mine. I became a Guardian in 1904. After Calcutt became a Guardian his custom increased and became very considerable. Sometimes the account would go on two or three weeks. Mrs. Calcutt would pay. I have done carting for Calcutt—sand, carrots and coal—about £3, which is not yet paid. I did not tell Calcutt I was about to become a Guardian and I never said to him, "When I get on the Board I shall hold out my hand." I knew Calcutt was working for Crowe in 1904. Calcutt never gave me a penny except for goods supplied. I have voted for and against him. Draper took exception to Calcutt's figure for the indestructible paint, I think. I don't remember Knight ever complaining of him. I have never received anything on the Board since I have been there. What Calcutt has said is a parcel of lies. In regard to the indestructible paint, my attention was called to the schedule of prices and I was under the impression there were to be two coats of varnish at 10d. a yard and that would make 1s. 8d. I thought it must be better if Calcutt charged 1s. 6d., and that is one of the reasons I voted for it. We were all members of the Scattered Homes Committee. I recommended work that I thought necessary. I voted against young

Barker's contract of December 22, 1904. I often used to go to Spooner's house to get a drink and collect money for a philanthropioal society of which I was chairman. There is no truth in the suggestion that I was to receive money from young Barker for voting for him on that contract, nor did I know of any Guardians doing so. I have never seen calcutt in spooner's house. I remember taking exception to something in one of Barker's contracts. My attention was called by an inmate to a very large hole half as big as this Court. He said, "Mr. Trott, go and look down there; they are digging a big hole there and taking lots of sand away." I went and looked at it and asked the foreman of the job about it, and he said he knew nothing of it I told my colleagues on the Board that Barker was taking the sand without the knowledge of the Guardians. I think Knight was remiss in his duty. He said it was being done for the lavatories, but they were right away from it. It was in 1907, or might be January, 1906. It was decided that young Barker should pay £100 for the sand he had taken. I did not think it enough. It is false that Mrs. Calcutt went upstairs and got £10 out of the safe when I called at the house, or any other sum. I went round for a Christmas account (£5 2s. 6d.) about 1905. The latter end of 1904 Calcutt gave me an overcoat. I never wear such a thing. I was going up the road and he came along and tapped me on the shoulder and said, "Where are you off to?" I said, "I am taking a stroll round." He said, "Come and have a drink. I am going to Loftus's; I am going to try some clothes on in Loftus's." I went with him, and he said, "Why don't you get measured for a suit of clothes?" I said, "I don't want any; I have two or three suits at home." He said, "The cold weather is coming on; why don't you get measured for an overcoat?" I said, "I don't want it." He said, "Here, shove the tape over him," and I said, "You are a bloomingnuisance." It wasdone in a moment, and that is how that transaction was done. I gave the coat to the carman to wear. I never thought it was given for anything I had done on the Board. I keep no books. I remember going to Southend with Allen and meeting Mrs. Calcutt on the front. Mrs. Calcutt begged me to get on the telephone. She said "Jim will be wild if you don't," and he came down. I believe they were staying in apartments. We went for a drive and lunched at his house. I also met him on another occasion, accidentally, going to the train coming home. Those are the only two occasions I was with Calcutt at Southend. It is not true that I was ever entertained by Calcutt to champagne in the "Shin Hotel" at Southend. It is an absolute lie. I was a regular attendant at the meetings of the Board. Whenever I voted for calcutt I did so conscientiously. When Calcutt was elected, the Guardians now charged supported him; but I think somebody had a spite against him. I heard someone say, "Why always Calcutt, why not give someone else a chance?" At Christmas, 1905, I had a present from Calcutt of a bundle of cigars and a bottle of whisky. No turkey. I used to have two or three come otherwise.
(Monday, August 3,)
WM. ARTHUR GIDNEY , Campbell Road, Bow, jobmaster. I met Trott, Cockerell, and Calcutt outside the "Drivers" public house on the Wednesday
before Easter, 1908. Calcutt left to go to Robinson, his solicitor, Trott did not say, "Stick tight, Jimmy, and they won't be able to do nothing." He only said, "Good evening."

Cross-examined. I work for Cockerell. Calcutt was not there a second. About June 11 I made a statement to Sergeant Ferrier that I had no recollection of anyone being with Cockerell or Calcutt that night. Cockerell afterwards recalled it to my memory.

WALTER TROTT (prisoner, on oath), recalled. Cross-examined. The turnover in my business has been about £60 to £70 a week for the last 18 years. It has decreased since the Inquiry. My shop is rented at £60 a years, and I keep a carman and a shopman. The profits are £3 to £4 a week. Calcutt was a customer before I went on the Board, and became a bigger customer since 1904; I have known him ten years. Stammers, Gould, Warren, and myself stood for election on one ticket. I and Grimes were great friends after my election. I do not know where he is. He never did as he liked with me. I did not follow him, I was not called "Grimes' dog." At Christmas, 1905, Mrs. Calcutt paid me £5 2s. 6d. Calcutt never paid me anything. After Calcutt's arrest he called when I was out, and I met him afterwards with Heward. He said nothing about £16. His object was to make up a case against the Guardians, so as to clear him
self. He came to entrap me. I twice borrowed money from Haseltine when on Spitalfields Market—that was about the Inquiry time. I was never in Calcutt's house with Grimes and Loftus or with either of them. Calcutt never spoke to me at the "Salisbury," about the drainage job at the laundry or said Knight wanted to take too much off. I voted for the 1s. 6d. at the full Board; there was a lot of argument about it. Knight would not pay more than 1s. I never discussed the question of Barker paying £300 or £400 on a contract at Spooner's. I was introduced to Barker, junior, at the banquet given by him on the laying of the foundation stone of the ex
tension building, just after my election. I have tried to get contract from the Bromley Guardians, but have not succeeded. Calcutt did not introduce me to any Guardian on the Bromley Board. I only know one whom I knew before as a personal friend. Symes was going in for the Nurses' Home contract, after Barker, junior, had been refused. I met Symes one Friday about 4 p.m., coming home from Stratford Market. Grimes took me to him. Symes said he was going to tender. I said I should vote for the lowest man. I never said I would influence the con
tract his way for a consideration; he has said that falsely out of spite. I never heard that Symes wrote to Thacker to complain of it. Warren called a meeting about an anonymous letter from somebody saying he had been recently visited by two members of the Board who said they were in a position to influence a contract. I never thought it was from Symes or that it alluded to me. The letter was long after my visit to Symes. It is not true that I telephoned to Symes. After I saw him Symes did meet me outside my shop. I said I was very busy and would see him later. I did not again see him. I never wore the overcoat given me by Calcutt, it was knocking about the shop; the carman used it or I might put it over my shoulders on a wet morning. I had nothing to do with the alteration of the book. Sam Loftus told me Calcutt had been there and asked him to alter it. I said, "You should not have done that; you are a mug to

go and alter that." Why Calcutt should give me an overcoat I cannot tell more than the man in the moon. I objected to send greengrocery to Southend and would not do it at the finish. I used Calcutt's carriage and paid the carman 7s. a day for it.

Re-examined. I attended the meeting about the anonymous letter and proposed that the writer should be advertised for, which I believe was done; it was in the local papers. I afterwards saw Barker, jun., and Symes together, and thought then the letter referred to me; that made me suspect Symes had written it because I had always run young Barker down, and said it was a scandalous shame he should get that contract, being £800 higher than the lower man, through his father backing him. I thought Knight was spiteful towards me, and that Barker had been coaxing up these other things; that was only my inference. Barker and Knight were extreme friends, and as I had got at that job about the sand, about which Barker had to pay £100 through me, I thought they had said, "Now we can get our own back." That is the way I saw it after
wards. At first I thought that old Barker, or someone from his firm, had written the anonymous letter, having heard from Symes that I had called on him. The letter did not suggest my name—that was first suggested at the Inquiry. Before I came on the Board I had tried to get contracts from Mile End, but did not get any. I have also tendered at Bromley and Whitechapel. I have been the lowest two or three times at Whitechapel but I never got it. I never succeeded in getting one yet. I am very glad I did not. My business takings have decreased ever since I became a Guardian.
(DEFENCE OF GILDER.)

SAMUEL GILDER (prisoner, on oath). I am Secretary to Friendly Societies, and from 1889 to 1902 Chief Clerk to the Soup Kitchen for the Jewish Poor, one of the largest institutions of that kind in London. In 1901, on my silver wedding, I received a valuable present. I have also taken a great part in charitable work amongst the poor and the Jews in the East End. I became a Guardian in 1904. Calcutt had then been four or five years the contractor, and was already reappointed for that year. He asked me to vote for him, and I said I should do so, all things being equal, he being the appointed tradesman and being on the spot. I was not corruptly influenced. Draper and I were at variance with regard to outdoor relief, of which I was in favour of our being more liberal; I also believed in giving local work to local men, and always insisted on Trades Union wages. With the exception of the indestructible paint I never voted against Knight. I was on the Finance and the Infirmary Visiting Committees. I had no conversation with Mrs. Calcutt about Calcutt repairing houses for Hirst. Calcutt asked me many times to spend a week-end at Southend, but I never went. In 1905 my wife and daughter went there for two or three days, and I went down on the Sunday with another daughter to fetch them home. I had not told Calcutt and did not myself know I was going until the last moment. I went to my wife's lodgings and ordered dinner; we went for a walk, met Mrs. Calcutt and her sister, Calcutt came up, we went for a stroll and appointed to meet

in the afternoon. I dined at my wife's lodgings and we went over to Calcutt's; he had two ponies and traps waiting. I went into his rooms for two or three minutes, had a glass of whisky. We all went for a drive and I returned to London that night. That is the only time I have ever been in Southend. I went to Herne Bay at the invitation of the Mayor of Stepney, Alderman Hirst, to inspect the children of the Scattered Homes. I dined with Hirst. Cal
cutt was already down there, I believe ill; I did not set him. I returned that same evening. I frequently called at Calcutt's office about the repairs he was doing on my houses. Heward sometimes sent me round to the house to see Calcutt. I frequently had drinks with Calcutt, I paying as frequently as he. I had one turkey from Calcutt, at Christmas, 1905. As we Jews do not eat meat or poultry not killed according to Jewish methods, I cut it up and gave it to two poor Gentiles I was assisting. There is not a word of truth in Calcutt's statement that he gave me £10. I had been financing as a sleeping partner a builder named Nash. I lost about £960 on the transaction. I gave him money to pay all debts, in
cluding one of £23 to Smith and Hill which he did not pay. Calcutt, being a customer of Smith and Hill, I asked him to try and settle it for £10; he did not succeed. I afterwards got old George Barker, who was also a customer of Smith and Hill, to try and settle it, which he did for £15, which I paid him. I had a few small houses. When I got on the Board Calcutt had been asking me to give him some work, and in 1905 I got him to do repairs. As I am a man of small means, especially after my building losses, I told him to send in his accounts quickly—not to run long bills. I continually asked for the account. I was applying for a renewal of the lease and had to make good dilapidations. I went with Calcutt to his solicitor, Forbes, and asked him to raise money for the purpose of paying Calcutt. Mr. Forbes said he could not do it. After that Calcutt visited me by appointment, and I offered to sell him the six houses and one in Bridge Street for £800; he offered £650, which I subsequently agreed to take. Of course, his bill was to come off that. He afterwards refused to go on with it. This was November 17, 1907. I ceased to be a Guardian in 1907. Calcutt has worked for me up to January, 1908, until he closed his yard. Calcutt was to collect the rents (about £2 a week) and pay himself for the repairs. Kemp, Loftus, and Stammers were on the opposite party to me, and knocked me out in 1907. When Calcutt was arrested Clancy was already collecting my rents as agent. I was dissatisfied with his management, and wrote him a warm letter which I asked him to read to Calcutt, who was then residing at Southend. When Calcutt was out on bail I got his address from Heward and went to see him—at Poplar. He was out, but we met in the street. Mr. and Mrs. Smith and Mrs. Calcutt and her baby were with him. We went in to have a drink. After some conversation about Clancy and his management of the houses, I said to him quite loudly—there was nothing private about it—" Do you know the rumours that are about—that Mr. and Mrs. Calcutt are going to give the whole show away?" said "Oh, that is all nonsense." He showed me some papers, and said "I would not retain these if I was going to do so." I said it was rumoured—I was not very serious in the matter—that that was the

rumour that was going round about all the Mile End Guardians, and goodness knows what not; I placed no importance on it. He said "I gave you £10." I said "What £10?" Of course, I concluded he was joking. He said "I gave it to your wife." I took no further notice as I thought he was joking. We had some drinks and after a little general conversation we parted. If he said anything more I did not hear it as I am rather deaf. Warren got up a subscription for Bryan, who was dying, to which I gave 10s. 6d. I think all the Guardians contributed, most of them much larger sums. I was not at the meeting at Spooner's. I never heard a word about Barker giving £300 to Guardians until it was said at the police court. On one occasion I voted for Barker, junr.; he was highly recommended by Knight and others for the quality of his work on a very large con
tract he had just completed. Barker was much below the highest tender. I understand he paid Trade Union wages. I had no corrupt motive. I never heard Knight complain that he could not get time sheets from Calcutt. Knight used to say, "I have only got these accounts yesterday," or "this morning—I suggest we give Calcutt so much on account"—and his suggestion was accepted. The accounts were afterwards certified by Knight with or without correction. With the exception of the indestructible paint I never voted against Knight's recommendation; I relied on him as a competent architect. As to the indestructible paint Knight suggested 1s.; Calcutt would not take less than 1s. 6d. The question had been discussed at ordinary and full Board meetings, and at public houses; we were very much against Knight having given the order without consulting us for the use of this paint, which caused extra expense in labour and cost. I think Hirst said at the Board" £700 odd is rather a tall order to give without consulting the Guardians." Knight said, "I did not know it was so much." I said, "You, an architect, give an order like that without knowing the quantities—are you acting as an architect or not?" We were greatly annoyed at the order being given at all, and in consequence, passed a resolution, "That the Committee are of opinion that neither the architect, builder. or other person should be allowed to give or execute orders contrary to the contract, specification, or schedule of prices without the express authority and permission of the Guardians." There was discussion at several meet
ings. Calcutt wrote that he would not accept less. We did not want to go to law and I formed an honest opinion it was better to par the 1s. 6d. I am not sure that I was present, as my name is not recorded, but I take the responsibility of the vote. I almost invariably left for home at 8 to 8.30 p.m.

Cross-examined: I should have voted for the 1s. 6d. if I was there—on several occasions I believe I voted for it. Under the circumstances I thought it was worth the money. Knight said it was not worth more than 9d. I assumed he knew the Guardians were dissatisfied with him for giving the order and that he wanted to work it out on Calcutt. I ad
vocated the erection of the Nurses' Home. I heard Draper had been writing to the Local Government Board without consulting the Board and I moved the adjournment with a view of censuring Draper. I was disgusted with the manner in which he met his opponents. I withdrew the motion

because I was satisfied the whole of the Guardians agreed with me. I seconded Hirst's motion that a letter be sent to the local Government Board stating all the facts, and was put on the deputation. I wished to show the Local Government Board we were acting fairly in taking Barker's tender, who was not the highest but who was a local man, employing local labour, and paying Trade Union Wages. I protested against the way the Board had been stigmatised by Draper and said, "Are we to take this lying down?" The Board had been said by Draper to be corrupt and rotten. I was present at the Board on November 5, 1904; December 2, 1904 (two contracts for Calcott); December 22, 1904 (three contracts for Calcutt); April 6, 1905 (Calcutt's tender the highest); September 7, 1905, Calcutt's tender was 5s. higher on one contract and on another £300 lower; on May 24, 1906; on july 12, 1906; February 14, 1907. I know I have voted against Calcutt on two or three occasions, but I cannot give the dates. I swear I was to pay Calcutt the £10 if he had settled the bill of Smith and Hill, and that I afterwards paid Barker the £15. I voted against the motion of Boiteau that contracts should not be given to relatives of Guardians. I did not see why the children should be punished because the father did public work. Barker, junior, lived at Forest Gate and his business address was Settle Street, New Road, at his father's place; I live about a dozen doors off on the opposite side of the road. I inquired, and he and his father showed me the books showing that the accounts were kept separately, and I was satisfied that it was so. I understand they have also satisfied the Local Government Board that it was a separate account. Towards the end of my time I learnt that most of the houses used for Scattered Homes belonged to Guardians or their relatives; they did with one exception—a house bought from Chiswick. He was a friend of mine shortly after I was on the Board. I did not know until the Inquiry that he had sold a pro
perty to the Board. I did not know Calcutt well before I went on the Board. I have visited his office frequently and been in his house perhaps 12 times since. A day or two previous to seeing Mr. and Mrs. Calcutt, after his arrest, I asked Heward whether Clancy had read my letter to Calcutt. He gave me Calcutt's address at Poplar. I went there. Mrs. Smith answered the door, told me they were not in, and I met Calcutt and Mr. and Mrs. Smith. I prevailed on them to come and have a drink, including Smith, as I understood Smith knew a lot of Calcutt's business. I said to Calcutt, "I am thoroughly dissatisfied with Clancy's working of these rents, his expenditure, expenses, etc When you are over your trouble I want you and me to have a thorough investigation into these accounts, because I do not think we are being treated rightly. Has he read that letter to you?" He said, "Yes." I said, "Then you know all about it." Then we got to general conversation. I said, "I suppose you have heard the rumour that is about?" He said, "There are lots of rumours about, are not there?" I said, "Yes." He said, "What one do you refer to?" I said, "Mrs. Calcutt said you are going to give the whole show away." There was no secret in the matter; it was ordinary con
versation. Then he pulled out some papers and said, "If I was going to do that should I retain these papers?" I said, "No." I did not think the matter very important; that ended that portion of the matter. He

afterwards said, "I gave you £ 10, did not I?" I took that as a joke and said, "What £ 10?" He said, "No, I did not give it to you, I gave it to your wife." I said, "Did you? I know nothing about it." This was after April 3. (Letter to Clancy of February 15, 1908, produced.) The letter I refer to is of later date.) I wrote to Calcutt asking him to call upon me." Give the show away" meant give all the Guardians away; there were many rumours. I did not think he was going to give me away—there was nothing to give me away for. I did not say it would be all right and that my wife would not say anything about the £10. As I went away I understood him to say, "How is your wife?" and I said, "She is all right." I never said to him, "Stick tight, Jim; you will be all right," or anything of the kind. I have been often in the "Three Crowns." Calcutt never stood me cham
pagne, nor Maitland. I do not know that Maitland was a contractor for drugs. Miss Auckland's evidence is untrue. I have never drunk cham
pagne at the "Three Crowns" on contract nights. I always left for home about 8.30. Calcutt worked on my houses in Granby Street to the amount of £80. I have not paid him yet—he is collecting the rents and paying him
self; that was the arrangement. During the Inquiry I asked him to buy the property—when I got a new lease. My offer is in the letter of Sep
tember 17, 1907: "I beg to accept your offer of £650 and think it will be to your interest to call on me to close the matter on Thursday morn
ing." "To your interest" is certainly not meant as a threat. I have had no quarrel with Knight. Knight charged me with blackmailing at the Inquiry, for which there will be other proceedings presently. There were some steel drums as to which he had wasted £400 of the ratepayers' money, and I moved that he should repay it. I went to see Knight before the meeting. He afterwards said I was blackmailing him. I never said, "You can stop my mouth if you like by paying." What I said was, "Are you prepared to pay half the cost of the drums (about £200) to the Guar
dians?" He said he would not pay the Guardians a brass farthing. I said, "We must see what we can do in the matter." He said, "I will be equal to the occasion and I will not spare you." We shook hands and met a few hours afterwards at the Board meeting. Knight did not accuse me of blackmailing him. The charge on my property of January 22, 1907, is for £190 for the dilapidations. £70 worth of the addi
tional bill for £80 was done before that. It was not put into the charge because Calcutt instructed his own lawyer. I have had a copy of the charge. I know nothing about Trott and Grimes' visit to Symes before the Inquiry came on. I will not deny I received Warren's circular—these little things escape my memory. I do not mean that is a little thing. When I went to the meeting I found it was a very serious thing. I did not know Trott and Grimes were the people implicated until the Inquiry. I did not telephone to Symes. I did not know him. I never asked him who the people implicated were.

Re-examined. I have never seen Symes. I know now that he is a builder. There was a waste of £400 on the two steel drums, and I pro
posed Knight should be held responsible. At the meeting Knight said I had threatened him and that I intended to move a resolution to get him dis
missed, which was untrue. I had seven houses altogether. I had the fag-end of the lease of one for about 18 months. On contract nights the Board usually sat

late. I am Secretary to a number of Friendly Societies, the members of which come to pay money to me in the evening, so I always got home at about 8 o'clock to 8.30. I never had any champagne; when I have had drinks I have always paid my share. I have added up the total of Calcutt's contracts during the time I was Guardian and they amount to £2, 648 10s. The total of other contractors is £2, 752. The result is a profit to the Ratepayers on that of £103 17s. That is taken from the official books. (To the Judge). That is to say if we had always had one contractor. Calcutt on the whole was the cheapest; if we took Calcutt for one thing and somebody else for another we might have saved more. Perhaps under unsatisfactory labour conditions we might have made paupers by bad priced labour and so have paid for our economy in another way. (To Mr. Mallinson). That is taking only the cases where Calcutt was accepted. I did not know Balls or Jackson or Johnson and Co., and should not have given them a contract; I would not refuse a Stepney man a job in order to put on a Brixton man; I should not give a contract to a man at Stratford. With regard to the contract for the workhouse dining hall where Calcutt was £98 15s. and another man £45 I voted for Calcutt on the advice of Knight—he said it could not be done at the price. I believe in buying in the cheapest market if the production is at a fair rate.

MRS. GILDER , wife of prisoner Gilder. I have lived in Mile End from 23 to 24 years. I have 12 children. Calcutt has frequently called to see Mr. Gilder about repairs—he has never given me £10. I went to South
end on a Saturday, did not know the Calcutts were there, we met them by accident on Sunday, went for a drive with them, left the same evening.

Cross-examined. I never heard about the £10 until the police court proceedings. I heard that the Guardians were implicated. I never heard it said that Calcutt was going to give the whole show away—my husband never told me; it was what I had read from the papers.

Mr. Justice Phillimore suggested that there was a difficulty with regard to the false pretences counts, First, in principle, that there must be an averment and proof that the person cheated believed the false pretence, whereas here a great many of the Guardians passed the bills without believing in them. Secondly, there was a difficulty, in detail, in the want of precise evidence as to the Guardians present when the bills were passed. What individuals were deceived?

The Attorney-General. In a case where the body is corporate it is not necessary to show that every member believed the statement; enough that there was a false pretence and the corporate body acted upon it; the Jury are entitled to draw a reasonable inference.
After further argument the Attorney-General withdrew the false pretences count.
(Tuesday August 4.)

Dr. TIMOTHY RICHARDSON , 530, Commercial Road, E. Mr.
JOHN ASH
BRIDGE , solicitor, Mr.
JOHN IGGLEDON , journalist, Mr.
F. J. HINTON and Mr.
A. J. W. BROWN , of Smithfield Market, were called as witnesses to the character of Gilson.

Dr. STANLEY ATKINSON gave evidence to character on behalf of Warren, and
FREDK. CRICHTON , licensed victualler, on behalf of Stammers.
[The remainder of this day was occupied by addresses of counsel, which continued on the 5th, 6th and 7th August.]

Verdict: 
                     
                     Each defendant, guilty of conspiracy and corruptly soliciting and receiving gifts; as to Loftus, not guilty in respect of count 24 (cor
ruptly receiving gifts of china clock on September 19, 1904); as to Hirst, not guilty on count 49 (corruptly receiving gift of diamond stud on August 1, 1901); as to Warren, not guilty on counts 66 and 67 (cor
ruptly agreeing to receive an advantage, to wit, profit on groceries supplied to Bryan, and corruptly receiving gift of £6 from Bryan); 
                  
                     
                     as to Gilson, we appeal for mercy respecting the gifts).

Sentences:
Each prisoner adjudged to be incapable of being elected to any public office for seven years, and to forfeit any public office now held by him; Gould,
15 months' hard labour and
£25 fine; Kemp,
six months' hard labour and
£25 fine; Loftus, Ridpath, Stammers, Trott, Gilder, each
nine months' hard labour and
£25 fine; Gilson,
£250 fine; Hirst,
two years' hard labour and
£250 fine; Warren,
one year's hard labour and
£250 fine.
Mr. Bodkin and Mr. Travers Humphreys prosecuted; Mr. F. E. Smith, M.P., and Mr. Ritter defended.

Mr. Bodkin, in opening the case, said the question here was one of law, the facts, not being disputed. The prosecution was under-taken by the Commissioner of Police under what was generally called the Betting House Act of 1853, which made it an offence for any person to keep or use any house or place for the purpose of money being received by the keeper of the house or place as a consideration for a promise to afterwards pay money on events and contingencies relating to horse-racing or any form of sport, including football. Under the Act defendant had the right either to be tried by the magistrate before whom he was summoned or before a jury. As a bookmaker, he had carried on an extensive business in ready money betting, and seemed to have thought, with regard to this Act of 1853, that, as in the case of a great many other Acts of Parliament, one had only to apply a little ingenuity to its language to enable one to go on as if there were no such Act. Therefore, as a means of getting out of the provisions of the Act, he adopted the expedient of having a clerk at Flushing, in Holland, who should receive the money there while the whole of the rest of the betting business was conducted at

his house, 738, Barking Road. According to the view on the law sub
mitted by the prosecution, that was not the way in which this Act of Parliament could be set at naught. By cases decided in the High Court and in the Court of Appeal, it had been well settled for six or seven years that if at the house of which the person accused is occupier material parts of the transaction of betting are carried on, it is immaterial that the money paid in regard to these betting transac
tions is not received from the customers or clients of the betting man at the house of which he is occupier, and, therefore, the expedient which the defendant had resorted to was nothing more nor less than wasted ingenuity and the law was too strong for him. Up to some years ago it used to be thought by many people, and not unlikely by those who are members of the legal profession, that the handing in of the betting slip or the letter containing the bet at the house occu
pied by the person accused must, in order to bring that transaction within the provisions of this Act, be accompanied by money or money's worth, and that the proprietor of the betting business carried on there must sit at the receipt of custom. But the decisions of the Courts had changed all that, and now it was quite immaterial where the money was received if the evidence satisfies the jury and the tribunal that at the premises mentioned in the indictment or accusa
tion material parts of the transaction of betting are in fact carried on. The learned counsel cited the cases of Stoddart v. Hawkes (1 L. R., K. B., 1902) and Lennox v. Stoddart (2 L. R., K. B., 1902, p. 21).

Chief-inspector
EDWARD DREW , Scotland Yard. By instruction of the Commissioner of Police, I placed myself in communication with the defendant on March 19, as a private individual, assuming the name of A. Shuter, Huddart Street, Burdett Road, Bow. I produce a copy of a postcard I sent to the defendant addressed to Rosedale House, 738, Barking Road, Plaistow, asking him to send me price lists and coupons and instructions how to act. In reply I received an envelope containing a number of documents, including the following. which gave several telephonic address numbers and a telegraphic address: "Robert Burrell, Flushing, Holland. London address: Rosedale House, 738, Barking Road, Plaistow, London, E. All bets must be made direct to my London address by telegram, telephone, or letter, and all money must be sent to Flushing, Holland, and must be posted not later than 12 a.m. for same day's racing. Commissions from 1s. upwards to any amount. Any number of deposit forms can be enclosed in the one envelope. Any money sent to London address will not be on, win or lose. When sending money to Flush
ing (Holland) bets can be made (same day) at my London address, providing your investment has been posted by 12 a.m. Time of post
ing will be taken from official postmark on envelopes upon their re
turn from my Flushing office. Daily or weekly settlements as re
quired. Books of rules and ready reckoner sent on application. Ac
count for the week closes Friday night, when statement will be for
warded for your further instructions." Attached to that by a perfora
tion

was a deposit form addressed to Mr. Robert Burrell, Flushing, Holland, at the foot of which was the following note: "When sending cheques, commissions cannot be executed until you are informed same is cleared." The documents also included the latest price list, start
ing price rules upon which defendant was prepared to do business, a telegraphic code, an investment and deposit form, a printed envelope addressed to Mr. Robert Burrell, Flushing, with a 2 1/2 d. stamp, a printed envelope addressed to Mr. R. Burrell, 738, Barking Road, with a 1d. stamp, a printed envelope, similarly addressed without any stamp, a number of green forms, to be filled up by any person who wished to bet upon the result of football matches, offering odds of 8 to 1 against any correct score, and quoting various odds defendant was prepared to give against the person betting selecting winners in one or more football matches. An example was also given of how the forms might be filled up. Having received these documents on March 22, I for
warded two postal orders for £1 each to Flushing, numbered respec
tively 684287 and 684288. I produce the letter with which I enclosed the postal orders, and to that letter I have since attached the counter
foils of the orders. The letter was as follows: "I am sending you on postal orders "(quoting the numbers)" for £1 each for bets that I am making at your London address for Lincoln Handicap." That letter I afterwards found in the office of Robert Burrell, 738, Barking Road, when I searched those premises. On the same day I sent the orders to Holland I wrote to defendant at his Barking Road address: "I have sent to your Flushing address by to-night's post postal orders Nos. 684287 and 684288 or £1 each. Please put me on 10s. each way on Bellatrix at 11 to 2 and Land League at 9 to 2 for Lincoln Handicap. If there is any to come, please let me have it as early as possible." Those prices were taken from the list he had sent me quoting the odds at which those horses stood at that time in the market. On May 24 I received an account of the bets I had made. On March 25 I forwarded another postal order for a sovereign to Flushing and I also found the letter enclosing it at the Barking Road address. I wrote on the same day to defendant at Barking Road, "Will you please put me on 2s. 6d. each way on Ben a Beg (lost 5s.) for the 4.40 p.m. race, West Derby Stakes (Liverpool meeting), 26th inst., or first time it runs, and 5s. each way on Kirkland for the Grand National (lost 10s.). I have forwarded to Flushing by to-night's post postal order No. 171938 for £1. Please send me some football coupons and investment forms, as I have mislaid the others." The word "lost" had been added in a different handwriting. That letter I also found at Barking Road when I searched the house. (Witness proceeded to detail other betting transactions with the defendant.) On April 9 I received at the West Ham Police Court a search warrant issued by Mr. Gillespie, stipendiary magistrate, and a warrant for the arrest of the defendant. I executed the warrants on the same day about one o'clock. 738, Barking Road, is a private house, double
fronted and containing, I think, nine rooms. I found defendant livng there with his wife and family. I told him who I was and read

the warrant to him. He said, "I have been expecting this. A man recently brought an action against me at Clerkenwell County Court. I beat him, and he threatened to put me away." I searched the prisoner and found on him nine postal orders for varying amounts, totalling £3 13s. 1d., £23 10s. in gold, £2 in silver, 10 betting slips, and 11 stamped envelopes addressed to himself, 15 similar envelopes with the Flushing address bearing the 2 1/2 d. stamp, 14 books of rules, 10 betting circulars, 10 private cards, with his name and address, quoting the telephone number, and a pocket book containing entries relating to betting. I found that the back room on the ground floor was fitted as an office and was used extensively in connection with the betting business. It was furnished with four tables and one clerk was sitting at one of the tables receiving telephone messages. There were six receivers in the room, and the clerk was devoting the whole of his attention to the messages which were being received and writing them down on a scribbling pad. He was also answering ques
tions about different horses. Between one p.m. and four p.m. or five p.m. 93 messages were received. I did not interfere with him and he did not interfere with me. He was attending solely to that part of the betting business. There were also a tape machine recording racing news, a copying press, these two large ledgers (produced), which are fairly full and relate to the credit betting business, a large quantity of betting circulars and betting slips and different papers and books, all relating to betting. The room was about 15 ft. square. The safe was locked, but defendant gave me the key. Inside the safe I found two postal orders—one for 5s. and the other for 2s. 6d., £21 10s. 6d. in silver, and £1 8s. in bronze, There were also bank books. Another room in the basement was devoted to the busi
ness. That was not furnished except with a table and was a sort of store room for betting papers. There was also a table which had apparently just been vacated by a clerk, who subsequently came in and, in the presence of the defendant, said he was the clerk. There were about 2, 000 envelopes addressed to different persons in the provinces, whom it was intended to circularise. While I was there some man came and dropped a note in the letter box. Hearing some
one moving away from the door, I went to the door and called him back again. The note in the letter box contained a betting slip relat
ing to horses named Detection, Maryport, Belle of Mayfair, and Ben a Beg, which were running on that day. The man admitted in the presence of the defendant that he had put the slip into the letter box. I said, "How did you come to do it?" He said, "I understood I had dealings with a man who was carrying on his business in Hol
land. I pay him the money there." Prisoner said, "That is all right." While I was there 19 letters were received by post—all re
lating to betting, seven of them from persons whose names appear in the book register as persons doing business with the defendant at Flushing. Sixteen express letters by messenger were also received, containing betting slips. These defendant explained were sent by men he employed to take bets from customers in the streets. I also found documents showing that a person named Pattison was employed

at the Flushing office. With respect to him, defendant said, "Patti
son is clerk at the Flushing office. All moneys he receives there he posts direct to my bank at Plaistow. At the time he does it he sends me an advice, and he generally sends over once a week, about every Monday." I found amongst the papers records of the amounts which I had sent to Flushing in the name of "A. Shuter," also a copy of a document by which defendant authorised Pattison to act as his agent. On April 13 I served a copy of the summons on the defendant personally at the same address.

Cross-examined. I make no complaint that I was not honestly treated in respect of these betting transactions—quite the contrary. It was not the first time I had made bets. I have made bets both professionally and unprofessionally. That I did not find myself in a criminal court may have been due to the fact that I did not make them in a "place." Before searching prisoner's premises I had been informed that prisoner had been to the police and said he thought his house was under observation, and if the police liked to go there he would point out anything they wanted to know. As to whether since the case of Stoddart was decided there has been any prosecution of a bookmaker similar to this, I can only speak with accuracy for the Metropolitan police, and there has not been, but a prosecution was launched against a bookmaker at Southport two months ago. The prosecution were not able to obtain a conviction without testing the other part of the question. I am aware that it is now a common practice for bookmakers to have a Dutch or foreign office, but that has only arisen since the passing of the Street Betting Act. I very seldom bet, but have sometimes done so when I have been on a racecourse. During the time I was at prisoner's house he gave me every assistance he could. There was no concealment of any kind. Prisoner told me at the last Sessions that he had abandoned the foreign office as the legality of the practice was to be tested, but I have not ascertained if the statement is true.
WILLIAM SYDNEY NASH , clerk in the General Post Office secretary's office, gave formal evidence with reference to the postal orders.

GEORGE ALFRED DEFRIES , clerk in the Plaistow branch of the London and Provincial Bank, produced a number of paying-in slips forwarded by Pattison to prisoner's account during March and April, representing £261 12s. 2d.

Verdict,
Guilty.

The Recorder (to prisoner).
The sentence is that you pay a fine of £100 to the King. I pass this sentence because I rather gather that the object is to try and raise this question. It must be clearly understood that if cases of this kind come before me I shall think it my duty to pass sentence of imprisonment, having regard to the great mischief which in my opinion arises from the use of houses in this way. I think that should be known.

Mr. Ritter. There is a certain amount of money in the hands of the police which it is not suggested was improperly come by. I sug
gest that it should be applied to the fine.
The Recorder. I have no power to make an order with regard to it. I have no doubt the police will do what is right in the matter.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
(Thursday, June 25.)

p.rs:
, stealing one reefer coat, one pipe, one chain with pendant, and one other chain, the goods of
George Johnson, and feloniously receiving the same.

div1.p: Mr. Daniel Warde prosecuted.

HANNAH JOHNSON , wife of George Johnson, 66, Pitfield Street, West Ham. On Monday, May 4, I had a back bedroom to let furnished at 3s. 6d. per week for a single man lodger. On that day prisoner called and took the room paying 6d. deposit. He slept at the house all that week. On the following Monday morning, May 11, I saw him when he came down. I gave him his breakfast, and after he had had his breakfast he asked me for a jug of hot water to go upstairs and wash, saying that he could not get his hands clean with cold water He came down again about a quarter to 10, and I said to him, "Will you please settle up with me before you go out, Mr. Wilson?" He then owed me 3s. 6d. (less 6d. the deposit), 6d. each morning for breakfast, and 1s. 6d. for his three meals on Sunday. He said, "presently." I said, "What is your presently?" He said, "I will be back by 12 o'clock, will that do?" I said, "It will have to do if you cannot give it to me now." He then went out, and did not come back any more. He still owes me the money. I did not intend him to return whether he paid me or not. I went upstairs into his room to see what he had left behind him. Then I went into my bedroom and found he had rifled my dressing-table. Then I looked across the bedroom at the cupboard door and found my husband's reefer coat was gone. In the pocket of the coat was my husband's pipe, a piece of gold chain, and my child's pendant with a photograph in it. I remember my husband breaking the pipe on the previous (Sunday) evening and his replacing the broken amber mouthpiece with a white bone mouthpiece. The pipe produced is my husband's pipe. I also identify the pendant, but the gold chain and reefer jacket have not been recovered. I next saw prisoner on the Wednesday following at the police station in custody. He was asked if he knew me and he said he did not, but I knew him only too well at the man who had lodged in my house for a week and had had breakfast every morning.
To Prisoner. I did not see you with the jacket.
To the Court. I have no other lodger.

GEORGE JOHNSON , 66, Pitfield Street. I am a labourer employed by the West Ham Gas Company. Prisoner was my lodger between May 4 and May 11. The pipe produced is mine, and I screwed the mouthpiece on on Sunday, May 10. I produce the broken amber mouthpiece. The child knocked the pipe off the mantelpiece. The chain and pendant produced are my child's. She was wearing it on the Sunday. She is not allowed to wear it at school because they break things about so, and she makes a practice of putting it into my pocket on the Sunday night when she takes it off. On Wednes
day,

the 13th, in consequence of something I heard, I went to the "Swan" public-house, where I saw prisoner. I said to him, "Good evening, Mr. Wilson." He said, "I do not know you." I said, "I have caught you once too often; I am going to claim you." I sent for a policeman. Prisoner came out of the "Swan" along with me. He was a little bit intoxicated, nothing to speak of. I sent for Con
stable 647K to come over and asked him to take him to the station down West Ham Lane. Prisoner then said, "It is all swank; I do not know this man." I have no doubt at all that prisoner is the man who lodged with me for a week. I always ring on where I work at six o'clock. Sometimes I return for breakfast at seven o'clock, sometimes a little after, according to the stores I have to get out and the district I am working. I last saw the coat on the Mon
day morning hanging on the cupboard door. It is like the one I am wearing, but of black cloth. I think prisoner might have worn it underneath his own.

In answer to prisoner, witness denied that prisoner was so drunk that the people in the "Swan" would not serve him and that he (pro
secutor) offered him a drink, saying, "I will give you a drink," and that prisoner handed him a shilling for the purpose.

Police-constable
ALBERT HEATH , 647K. About 20 minutes past 12. on May 13, I was called to the "Swan" at Stratford by Johnson. Prisoner was there and Johnson said, "I want to give this man in charge." I said, "What for?" He said, "He lodged with me for a week and went away on Monday taking my reefer coat, pipe, piece of gold chain, piece of metal chain, with my little girls pendant with a portrait in it." Prisoner said, "I do not know this man. It is all swank. You ought not to take me. I am a Great Eastern porter." I took him to the station, where he was charged. He made no reply. When searched, we found this pipe (produced) and this pendant and piece of chain, which have been identified by John
son. He had 6d. in bronze on him. Inquiries were made of the Great Eastern Railway, but nothing was known of him there.

CHARLES WILSON (prisoner, on oath) denied that he knew anything at all about the pipe, the jacket, or the piece of chain. The pipe, he declared, was found in the cells. He admitted, however, that he was the man who had lodged with the Johnsons.

Verdict,
Guilty. Prisoner confessed to a previous conviction for felony.

Detective WESTON , T Division, said he was present at North Lon
don Sessions on April 3, 1906, when prisoner was sentenced to 21 months' hard labour, in the name of Charles Miller, for stealing sheets from a Rowton lodging house. There had been several com
plaints that working men were losing money from their pockets, and he himself slept at the Rowton House for three weeks in order to find out who the thief was. Suspecting prisoner, he stopped him, and on searching him found a number of sheets wrapped round his body, and in his room was found a stick with a hook at the end with which he abstracted men's trousers from adjoining cubicles so that he might rifle the pockets. On the occa
sion

of his last conviction 10 convictions were proved against him. On the last occasion when he was at North London Sessions he denied all his convictions, and he was put back till the following sessions in order that, warders might be brought from various prisons to identify him, and Mr. Loveland-Loveland said he was the most confirmed liar he had ever met with in his life.

The Recorder observed that prisoner caused great inconvenience here at the last sessions. A jury had been sworn and the trial com
menced, when prisoner asked that it might be postponed in order that he might have the opportunity of calling witnesses to prove his identity. The jury therefore had to be discharged, as otherwise prisoner would have said he had been prevented calling witnesses by the wickedness of the court.

Detective Weston said that prisoner after his last sentence peti
tioned the Home Office, stating that all the witnesses had committed perjury, and that the women employed, respectable hard
working women, had put the sheets on him. Prisoner had never done any work. Witness had known him about eight years. He went from place to place robbing lodgings. He worked by himself, and usually disposed of things to dealers with second-hand stalls. He did not drink, and was very quiet. Witness was unable to say anything in his favour.

Sentence,
Five years' penal servitude.
BEFORE JUDGE RENTOUL.
(Monday, June 29.)

div0.p: BRAY, John (43, meter inspector), who pleaded guilty last sessions of a common law forgery and uttering (see page 160) came up for judgment.

Mr. Metcalfe, appearing for the prisoner, stated that communication had been made to the West Ham Corporation sitting on Thursday, and they came to the conclusion that having regard to the number of their employees they would not be justified in taking prisoner back into their service.
Sentence, Three months' imprisonment in the second division.
